legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: A new Digital Nomad Visa was adopted in mid-2024, amending the Foreigners in the Republic of Bulgaria Act. It requires remote work for a foreign company, sufficient funds, and health insurance. It is a type of long-stay 'Type D' visa.
legal_pathways.self_employment: Foreigners can register a company (typically an EOOD/OOD) and obtain a D-visa on the grounds of conducting commercial activity, which requires hiring at least 10 Bulgarian citizens.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: Residency can be obtained via a significant investment (over ‚Ç¨512,000) in real estate or a business, which can lead to a Golden Visa.

tax_system.non_resident_tax: Non-residents are taxed at a 10% flat rate on income from Bulgarian sources.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: Available for non-EU/EEA nationals working for a foreign-registered company. Granted for up to 1 year and is not renewable consecutively.

legal_pathways.investment_visa: No direct investment visa, but residency can be obtained through establishing a business that meets certain economic criteria.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Holders of the digital nomad permit are exempt from paying Croatian income tax on their foreign-sourced remote work income.
tax_system.special_regimes: For standard residents (not digital nomads), income is taxed progressively up to ~35.4% depending on municipal surcharges.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Not applicable to digital nomad permit holders regarding their foreign income. Other Croatian-sourced income would be taxed.

contribution_rates.self_employed: Standard self-employed residents pay significant contributions for pension (20%) and health insurance (16.5%).

benefits.healthcare: Digital nomads must have comprehensive private health insurance covering them in Croatia for the duration of their stay. They do not access the public HZZO system.
benefits.pension: No access to the state pension system.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity. Can be applied for online or in-person at a local police station. Requires significant paperwork, including apostilled criminal record checks. Processing can take 30-60 days.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Can be opened by non-residents with a valid passport and, in some cases, an OIB (Croatian personal identification number), which is easily obtainable.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: Available for non-EU/EEA nationals with a net monthly income of ‚Ç¨3,500. Can be renewed for a total of 3 years.
legal_pathways.self_employment: Requires registering as self-employed with the tax department and social insurance services. This is a common path for EU citizens or those with other residency rights.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: A 'Golden Visa' program offers permanent residency through a significant real estate investment (minimum ‚Ç¨300,000).

tax_system.non_resident_tax: Non-residents are taxed only on income generated within Cyprus.

contribution_rates.employed: Digital Nomads are generally not required to pay if they are contributing elsewhere. If they do register, contributions are 8.3% for employee and 8.3% for employer.
contribution_rates.self_employed: For registered self-employed, the rate is 15.6% of assumed income, plus a mandatory 4% contribution to the General Healthcare System (GeSY).

benefits.healthcare: Contributions to GeSY grant access to the public healthcare system. Digital Nomad visa applicants must show proof of private health insurance regardless.
benefits.pension: Contributions to the social insurance fund build entitlement to the state pension.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity. The application must be submitted in person at the Civil Registry and Migration Department (CRMD) in Nicosia after arrival. Processing takes 1-3 months.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Relatively straightforward. Requires a valid passport, proof of address, and sometimes a letter of reference. Can be opened by non-residents.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Typical southern European bureaucracy; can be slow with a focus on paperwork. Using a legal firm for immigration matters is common.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: Available for non-EU/EEA nationals. Requires proof of remote work and a monthly income of ‚Ç¨4,500 before tax.

contribution_rates.self_employed: Self-employed individuals registered in Estonia must pay the 33% social tax on their business income.

benefits.pension: A comprehensive three-pillar pension system.

‚Ä¢ Key benefit is registering as an 'Individual Entrepreneur' to access the 1% tax rate on turnover up to 500,000 GEL.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The 'Remotely from Georgia' program provides a legal basis for stay. However, the visa-free regime (365 days for many nationalities) is more commonly used.
legal_pathways.self_employment: The most popular path is to arrive visa-free, register as an 'Individual Entrepreneur', and apply for 'Small Business Status' to access the 1% tax rate.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: Residency can be obtained via an investment of at least $300,000 USD in real estate or other assets.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: A 20% flat rate on Georgian-source income for regular employees or residents not using a special regime.
tax_system.special_regimes: The 'Small Business Status' for Individual Entrepreneurs taxes business turnover up to 500,000 GEL (approx. $180,000) at just 1%. There is no tax on foreign-sourced income that is not brought into Georgia.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Non-residents are taxed at 20% on their Georgian-source income.

contribution_rates.employed: A 2% contribution to the pension fund is deducted from the employee's salary, with the employer contributing an additional 2%.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Individual Entrepreneurs with Small Business Status are not required to make social security or pension contributions.

benefits.healthcare: A basic universal public healthcare system exists, but coverage is limited. All foreigners, including those on the nomad program, are required to have private health insurance.
benefits.pension: A mandatory funded pension scheme exists for employees, but not for Individual Entrepreneurs.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Extremely simple for eligible nationalities due to the 1-year visa-free policy. The 'Remotely from Georgia' application is also straightforward and online.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Very easy. Can be opened in under an hour with just a passport at major banks like TBC or Bank of Georgia. Multi-currency accounts (GEL, USD, EUR) are standard.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Highly efficient and transparent. Registering as an Individual Entrepreneur can be done in one day at a Public Service Hall ('House of Justice'). Georgia consistently ranks among the top countries globally for 'Ease of Doing Business'.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: Germany does not have a dedicated digital nomad visa. The primary route is the 'Residence Permit for the Purpose of Freelance Activity' (Aufenthaltserlaubnis zur Aus√ºbung einer freiberuflichen T√§tigkeit - ¬ß 21 Abs. 5 AufenthG).
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is the essence of the freelance visa. It is designed for 'liberal professions' (Freiberufler) like artists, journalists, and IT consultants. It requires having German-based clients.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: A 'Residence permit for self-employed business people' is available for those establishing a commercial business (Gewerbe), requiring a business plan showing economic benefit to Germany and secured financing. The requirements are generally stricter than for freelancers.

tax_system.special_regimes: No special tax regimes exist for expats or nomads. You are subject to the standard German tax system upon establishing residency.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Non-residents are taxed only on German-source income, with rates varying depending on the income type.

contribution_rates.employed: Contributions are roughly 20-21% for the employee and 20-21% for the employer, covering health, pension, unemployment, and long-term care insurance.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Freelancers are required to have German health insurance (public or private). Public insurance is ~14.6% of income, plus an additional provider-specific rate (~1.7%). Pension contributions are optional for most freelancers but mandatory for some (e.g., teachers, artists via KSK).

benefits.healthcare: Excellent and comprehensive universal healthcare system. It is mandatory for all residents to be insured.
benefits.pension: Robust, contributory state pension system.
benefits.unemployment: Comprehensive coverage for employees who have contributed to the system.

bureaucracy.visa_process: High complexity. Must be applied for from your home country and involves extensive documentation (business plan, financing plan, letters of intent from German clients, CV, etc.). Can take 3-6 months to process.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Relatively easy to open once you have registered an address (Anmeldung). Difficult without a registered address.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Famous for its high level of bureaucracy. Requires in-person appointments for nearly everything (address registration, visa appointments, tax office). Processes are paper-based, slow, and almost exclusively in German. Patience is essential.

visas.bonuses_incentives: Easy eligibility, fast process.
visas.remarks:
üë§ Strictly for individuals; no family inclusion allowed.
‚Ä¢ Straightforward online application via 'Enter Hungary' portal.
‚Ä¢ Income requirement of ‚Ç¨3,000/month as of 2024.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The 'White Card' is Hungary's official digital nomad residence permit. It is available to non-EU/EEA nationals who work remotely for a foreign company or as a freelancer for foreign clients.
legal_pathways.self_employment: An alternative is a residence permit for the purpose of 'pursuing a gainful activity', which is more complex and intended for those serving the Hungarian market.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: The 'Guest Investor Program' (Golden Visa) was relaunched in 2024, requiring a minimum investment of ‚Ç¨250,000 in real estate funds, ‚Ç¨500,000 in property, or a ‚Ç¨1,000,000 donation.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: A 15% flat rate. White Card holders are exempt from Hungarian tax for the first 183 days. If they stay longer and become a tax resident, their worldwide income is subject to the 15% tax.
tax_system.special_regimes: For freelancers, a 'flat-rate taxation' (√°tal√°nyad√≥z√°s) system is available, allowing for a 40% or 60% deemed cost allowance before the 15% tax is applied, which can be very beneficial.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: White Card holders are considered non-residents for tax purposes for the first six months.

contribution_rates.employed: Employee pays 18.5% (social security contribution). Employer pays 13% (social contribution tax).
contribution_rates.self_employed: Under the flat-rate tax regime, freelancers pay 18.5% Social Insurance Contribution (TB) and 13% Social Contribution Tax (szocho) on a calculated base, which has minimum thresholds tied to the national minimum wage.

benefits.healthcare: White Card holders must have comprehensive private health insurance. If they become residents and pay social security, they can access the public system.
benefits.pension: Contributions build entitlement to the state pension.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity. The application can be started online via the 'Enter Hungary' platform, but biometrics must be submitted at a Hungarian consulate. Processing time is officially up to 30 days but can take longer.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Relatively straightforward to open with a passport and proof of address (like a rental agreement). A residency permit is often required.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The system can be bureaucratic, and while digital platforms exist, many processes still require in-person visits. The language barrier is significant outside of Budapest.
bureaucracy.source: https://hungarygoldenvisa.io/guides/hungary-white-card/

visas.bonuses_incentives: No tax if stay is less than 183 days.
visas.remarks:
‚ùÑÔ∏è Ideal for a short-term, unique experience.
‚Ä¢ Very high income requirement (ISK 1,000,000/month for individuals, ISK 1,300,000/month for couples).
‚Ä¢ Visa is non-renewable, you must leave after 6 months.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: A 'Long-term visa for remote workers' is available for non-EU/EEA citizens for up to 180 days. Requires a high monthly income of ISK 1,000,000 (~$7,200 USD).
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the remote work visa; you must prove you are self-employed in a foreign country. Starting a local Icelandic business is a separate, more complex process.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: Iceland does not have a formal residency-by-investment or 'Golden Visa' program.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Holders of the remote work visa are exempt from Icelandic income tax as they are not considered residents. For residents, a progressive system applies: 31.49% on income up to ISK 472,005/month, 37.99% up to ISK 1,325,127/month, and 46.29% on income above that (rates include municipal tax).
tax_system.special_regimes: No special regimes apply to remote workers.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Not applicable to remote work visa holders on their foreign income.

contribution_rates.employed: Remote workers are exempt. For residents, employees pay 4% for pension, and employers pay ~6.35% payroll tax and an 8% pension contribution.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Remote workers are exempt. Resident freelancers make significant contributions to their own pension funds.

benefits.healthcare: Remote work visa holders must have private health insurance and do not access the public system. Residents have access to a high-quality universal public healthcare system.
benefits.pension: A mandatory, three-pillar pension system exists for residents.
benefits.unemployment: Comprehensive coverage for residents who have contributed.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity. The application is submitted by mail or in person to the Directorate of Immigration in Iceland. Processing time is officially 3-4 weeks but can be longer. Requires a clean criminal record and comprehensive health insurance.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Difficult for temporary visitors. Requires an Icelandic ID number (Kennitala), which is generally only granted to residents staying longer than 3-6 months.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Processes are efficient and well-organized but very strict. Digital services are common, but the initial residency/visa process requires precise paperwork.
bureaucracy.source: https://theworkingtraveller.com/iceland-digital-nomad-visa/

visas.bonuses_incentives: N/A
visas.remarks:
‚ùå No digital nomad visa currently exists.
‚Ä¢ Alternative visa options are not suitable for remote work for foreign companies. Plans have been discussed but not implemented.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: As of mid-2025, Ireland does not offer a specific Digital Nomad Visa. The government has discussed plans, but no program has been launched.
legal_pathways.self_employment: The 'Start-up Entrepreneur Programme (STEP)' is for non-EEA nationals with an innovative business idea and funding of ‚Ç¨50,000. It is not suitable for typical freelancers.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: The 'Immigrant Investor Programme' was closed to new applications in February 2023.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Progressive rates of 20% (standard rate) and 40% (higher rate). For a single person in 2025, the 40% rate applies to income over ‚Ç¨42,000.
tax_system.special_regimes: The 'Special Assignee Relief Programme (SARP)' offers tax relief for high-earning executives moving to Ireland, but it does not apply to freelancers or nomads.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Individuals resident for less than 183 days are generally not tax resident. If tax residency is established, worldwide income is taxed.

contribution_rates.employed: Pay Related Social Insurance (PRSI) is paid by both employee (4%) and employer (typically 11.05%). The rates are scheduled to increase slightly in October 2025.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Class S PRSI for self-employed individuals is a flat 4% of all income, subject to a minimum annual contribution.

benefits.healthcare: Ireland has a two-tier system. Access to the public system is based on residency and means. Many residents opt for private health insurance for faster access to services.
benefits.pension: A contributory state pension system exists for those who have paid sufficient PRSI contributions.
benefits.unemployment: Comprehensive coverage for those who have contributed through employment.

bureaucracy.visa_process: N/A for a nomad visa. Other long-stay permits are known to be document-heavy and moderately slow to process.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Moderately difficult. Requires both proof of identity (passport) and proof of address in Ireland (utility bill, government letter), which is a challenge for new arrivals. Appointments are often needed.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Moderate bureaucracy. Obtaining a Personal Public Service (PPS) number is a crucial first step for any interaction with state services, including employment and housing.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official guidelines and expat experiences.

visas.visa_name: Visa for Remote Workers and Digital Nomads
visas.visa_length: 1 year with the possibility to extend
visas.bonuses_incentives: Includes family, health insurance required.
visas.remarks:
üéì Requires 'highly skilled worker' status (degree or 3-5 years' high-level experience). Minimum annual income of ~‚Ç¨28,000.
‚Ä¢ Must apply in person at an Italian consulate.
‚Ä¢ Within 8 days of arrival, must apply for a residence permit (Permesso di Soggiorno).

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: Available since April 2024 for non-EU 'highly skilled' workers. Requires a minimum annual income of ~‚Ç¨28,000, private health insurance, and proof of accommodation.
legal_pathways.self_employment: The standard 'lavoro autonomo' visa is an alternative but is subject to annual quotas ('decreto flussi') and is generally more difficult to obtain.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: An 'Investor Visa for Italy' is available, requiring a significant investment starting from ‚Ç¨250,000 in an innovative startup or up to ‚Ç¨2 million in government bonds.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Progressive rates (IRPEF). For 2025, the brackets are: 23% up to ‚Ç¨28,000; 35% from ‚Ç¨28,001 to ‚Ç¨50,000; and 43% above ‚Ç¨50,000.
tax_system.special_regimes: A favorable 'impatriate' tax regime exists, potentially reducing taxable income by 70% (or 90% in southern regions) for up to 5 years, but the Digital Nomad visa's interaction with this regime is still being clarified.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Becoming a tax resident (staying >183 days) subjects you to tax on worldwide income. Specific tax advice is crucial.

contribution_rates.employed: The employer pays ~24% and the employee pays ~9% of gross salary to the National Institute for Social Security (INPS).
contribution_rates.self_employed: Freelancers not part of a professional guild must enroll in the 'Gestione Separata' INPS fund, with contribution rates of ~26.07% of their net income.

benefits.healthcare: Upon registering for residency, individuals gain access to the National Health Service (SSN), which provides comprehensive care. Private health insurance is required for the initial visa application.
benefits.pension: Contributory state pension system.
benefits.unemployment: Coverage is primarily for those who have lost traditional employment.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Very high complexity. The visa must be obtained from an Italian consulate abroad. Upon arrival, the most critical and difficult step is applying for the residence permit ('permesso di soggiorno') at the local police headquarters ('Questura') within 8 days. This process is notoriously slow and convoluted.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Can be opened with a passport and an Italian tax code ('codice fiscale'), which is relatively easy to obtain. However, some banks may require the residence permit.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Italy is famous for its slow, paper-based, and often confusing bureaucracy. Language barriers, long queues, and unclear procedures are common. Professional assistance from a lawyer or 'commercialista' (accountant) is highly recommended.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official procedures and extensive expat reporting.

visas.eligible_citizens: Non-EU nationals who are employed by or are a board member of a foreign-registered company in an OECD country, or are a registered self-employed person in an OECD country for at least 6 months.
visas.bonuses_incentives: Schengen access.
visas.remarks:
üåê Eligibility is restricted to citizens or employees/freelancers registered in OECD countries.
‚Ä¢ Relatively high income requirement for the region (2.5x the average national salary, approx. ‚Ç¨2,900/month).
‚Ä¢ Application must be done in person at a Latvian consulate.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: Available for non-EU nationals working for a company or as a freelancer registered in an OECD member state. Requires an income of at least 2.5 times the average Latvian salary.
legal_pathways.self_employment: Foreigners can register as self-employed (pa≈°nodarbinƒÅtais) or establish a company (SIA), but this path to residency is more complex than the nomad visa and is intended for those serving the local market.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: A residence permit can be obtained via an investment of at least ‚Ç¨250,000 in government bonds or ‚Ç¨50,000 in the capital of a Latvian company (plus a ‚Ç¨10,000 state fee).

tax_system.personal_income_tax: If staying less than 183 days, no tax is owed. If tax residency is established, progressive rates apply: 20% on income up to ‚Ç¨20,004/year; 23% up to ‚Ç¨78,100; and 31% above that.
tax_system.special_regimes: A 'Micro-enterprise tax' (MET) regime exists for small businesses with revenue under ‚Ç¨40,000, taxing revenue at a 25% rate, which covers social contributions and personal income tax.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Non-residents are taxed only on Latvian-source income.

contribution_rates.employed: If employed by a Latvian company, the employee pays 10.5% and the employer pays 23.59%. Digital nomads are generally not required to pay if contributing elsewhere.
contribution_rates.self_employed: For resident freelancers, the standard rate is 31.07% on income, plus an additional 10% for pension on income exceeding a certain threshold.

benefits.healthcare: Digital nomad visa holders must have private health insurance. Residents contributing to the social tax system have access to state-funded healthcare.
benefits.pension: Contributory state pension system for residents.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity. The D-visa application and supporting documents must be submitted in person at a Latvian embassy or consulate. Processing time is approximately 15-30 days.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Moderately difficult. Non-residents may face enhanced scrutiny due to strict anti-money laundering (AML) regulations. An in-person visit is required, along with proof of identity and source of funds.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The system is generally efficient but formal and document-heavy. English is widely spoken in Riga, but less so in government offices outside the capital.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official guidelines and expat experiences.

visas.bonuses_incentives: Pathway to EU long-term residency after 5 years, access to EU social safety net.

cost_of_living.accommodation: ~$800/month for a one-bedroom apartment in Vilnius city center.
cost_of_living.overall_index: Low. Significantly more affordable than Western Europe or the Caribbean.

visas.remarks: üá±üáπ This is a two-step process: first, register for 'individual activity' with the tax authority (VMI), then apply for the Temporary Residence Permit (TRP) via the MIGRIS portal. A National (D) Visa may be needed to enter while the TRP is processed. An in-person appointment for biometrics is mandatory.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The TRP for 'Individual Activity' is the de-facto pathway for self-employed remote workers.
legal_pathways.startup_visa: A streamlined TRP for founders of innovative startups, valid for 2 years and renewable for 3.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: A TRP is available for shareholders of a Lithuanian company that meets certain equity and operational criteria.
legal_pathways.other: A standard TRP for employment with a Lithuanian company is also available.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: For 'individual activity', tax is progressive from 5% to 15% on taxable income. For standard employment, it is 20% or 32% depending on income.
tax_system.special_regimes: The individual activity tax regime is significantly lower than standard employment tax.

contribution_rates.self_employed: Mandatory contribution of 19.5% on a base of 90% of taxable income to the SODRA fund.

benefits.healthcare: Full access to the state-funded public healthcare system.
benefits.pension: Entitlement to a state pension based on contributions.
benefits.unemployment: Access to unemployment benefits, paid sickness leave, and paid maternity leave.

bureaucracy.visa_process: High. The TRP application via the MIGRIS portal is a complex, document-heavy procedure requiring a mandatory in-person visit for biometrics.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Moderately difficult. Typically requires an in-person visit and proof of a legal basis for residency in Lithuania (e.g., TRP or individual activity registration).
bureaucracy.general_admin: Reflects a standard, regulated EU member state system. Processes are well-defined but can be slow and require strict adherence to rules.
bureaucracy.source: https://www.migracija.lt/en/home

visas.bonuses_incentives: No local tax if taxed elsewhere.
visas.remarks:
üá≤üáπ Fully remote application process. Income requirement is ‚Ç¨42,000 gross per year as of 2025.
‚Ä¢ Tax-exempt if you maintain tax residency elsewhere.
‚Ä¢ Income requirements increase for any accompanying family members.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The 'Nomad Residence Permit' is available for non-EU nationals with a gross annual income of ‚Ç¨42,000.
legal_pathways.self_employment: EU citizens can easily register as self-employed. Non-EU citizens have a much more complex path requiring a business plan and demonstrating value to the Maltese economy.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: Malta offers 'Citizenship by Naturalisation for Exceptional Services by Direct Investment', requiring a significant investment (e.g., ‚Ç¨600,000+) and a period of residency.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: For single individuals, rates are progressive: 0% up to ‚Ç¨12,000; 15% up to ‚Ç¨16,000; 25% up to ‚Ç¨60,000; and 35% above that. (Note: These are 2025 rates).
tax_system.special_regimes: Nomad Residence Permit holders who are not tax resident in another jurisdiction may be subject to a 10% tax on their foreign-sourced income declared in Malta. Non-domiciled residents are taxed on foreign income only if it is remitted to Malta.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: If you maintain your tax residency elsewhere and pay taxes there, you are not liable for Maltese income tax.

contribution_rates.employed: Both employer and employee contribute 10% on salaries up to a certain ceiling.
contribution_rates.self_employed: A rate of 15% of annual net income from the previous year, with minimum and maximum weekly payments.

benefits.healthcare: Nomad permit holders must have private health insurance. Residents contributing to the social security system have access to Malta's free public healthcare.
benefits.pension: Contributory state pension system for residents.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity. The application is handled online by the Residency Malta Agency. Processing officially takes around 30 working days. After approval, applicants must travel to Malta to provide biometrics for the residence card.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Can be challenging. Requires a Maltese address and thorough due diligence (KYC) checks. The process often involves significant paperwork and in-person appointments.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The system is a mix of British-influenced efficiency and Mediterranean bureaucracy. While many services are online, processes can be slow and require persistence. English is an official language, which is a major advantage.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official guidelines and expat experiences.

visas.bonuses_incentives: Income tax exemption for at least two years.
visas.remarks:
üèîÔ∏è Long duration: stay up to 4 years. Income requirement is 3x the minimum wage (~‚Ç¨1,350/month). 
‚Ä¢ Program is active and applications are submitted in person in Montenegro.
‚Ä¢ Low income requirement makes it very accessible.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The 'privremeni boravak' (temporary residence) for digital nomads is available. It allows a 2-year stay, renewable for another 2. Applications are submitted in-country.
legal_pathways.self_employment: Residency can be obtained by establishing a Montenegrin company (d.o.o.) and appointing yourself as the executive director. This requires monthly tax and social security payments.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: The Citizenship by Investment program was officially closed in 2022. Residency can be obtained by purchasing property, with no minimum value, but this does not grant the right to work.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Digital nomad visa holders are exempt from income tax for the duration of their permit. For other residents, a progressive rate applies: 9% on income up to ‚Ç¨1,001/month, and 15% on the amount exceeding it. This has been updated to a single 15% rate starting from 2025.
tax_system.special_regimes: The digital nomad visa provides a significant tax advantage.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Non-residents are taxed only on income sourced from Montenegro.

contribution_rates.employed: For residents, the employee pays 15.5% and the employer pays 6% on gross salary.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Resident freelancers pay contributions based on a chosen base, covering pension, disability, and health insurance.

benefits.healthcare: Digital nomad visa holders must have private health insurance. Residents contributing to the system can access public healthcare.
benefits.pension: Contributory state pension system for residents.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity. Applications are submitted in person at the Ministry of Internal Affairs in the municipality of residence. This means you must enter Montenegro first (e.g., as a tourist). Required documents must be translated into Montenegrin.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Relatively straightforward. Can be opened with a passport and proof of address. A deposit may be required.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The system can be bureaucratic and slow, with processes varying between municipalities. A local facilitator or 'bookkeeper' is often used to navigate the system, especially for company formation and residency.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official guidelines and expat experiences.

visas.eligible_citizens: All nationalities (specific, easier path for US and Japanese citizens)
visas.bonuses_incentives: Can register business and work freelance.
visas.remarks: üå∑ This is an alternative path, not a true nomad visa. Requires a points-based assessment of your business plan and its value to the Dutch economy. A much easier path exists for US citizens (DAFT) and Japanese citizens, who are exempt from the points system. (Approximation: Visa cost converted from ‚Ç¨1,557 fee in 2025).

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The 'Residence permit for self-employed persons' is the primary route for freelancers (ZZP'ers). It does not have a minimum income requirement but uses a points-based system evaluating the applicant's experience and business plan's benefit to the Dutch economy.
legal_pathways.self_employment: The Dutch-American Friendship Treaty (DAFT) and a similar treaty with Japan provide a much simpler path for US and Japanese citizens, exempting them from the rigorous points-based evaluation.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: A residence permit for foreign investors is available for those who invest a minimum of ‚Ç¨1,250,000 in an innovative Dutch company or fund.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Worldwide income is taxed in a 'box' system. Box 1 (employment/business income) is progressive up to 49.50% (for income above ~‚Ç¨77,000 in 2025). Box 2 is for substantial business interests. Box 3 taxes wealth (savings/investments) based on a deemed rate of return.
tax_system.special_regimes: The '30% ruling' is a significant tax advantage for skilled employees hired from abroad, allowing 30% of their gross salary to be paid tax-free. However, this is generally not available to self-employed individuals unless they set up a BV (limited company) and employ themselves, which is a complex structure.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Non-residents are taxed only on Dutch-source income.

contribution_rates.employed: National insurance contributions are levied within the first tax bracket of Box 1 income, totaling 27.65%. Employee insurance schemes are paid by the employer on top of this.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Freelancers (ZZP'ers) are not covered by employee insurance schemes (unemployment, disability). They are required to pay a contribution for the Health Insurance Act (Zvw), which is 5.32% of their profit (as of 2024), and must take out their own mandatory health insurance.

benefits.healthcare: A high-quality, mandatory private health insurance system. All residents must purchase a basic policy. Costs vary but are generally high.
benefits.pension: The state pension (AOW) is covered by national insurance. Freelancers are responsible for arranging their own supplementary pensions.
benefits.unemployment: Freelancers are not entitled to unemployment (WW) or state disability (WIA) benefits and are encouraged to seek private insurance for this.

bureaucracy.visa_process: High complexity for non-DAFT/Japanese applicants. The application is submitted to the Dutch Immigration and Naturalisation Service (IND) and requires an extensive, well-researched business plan. Processing time is officially 90 days but can be longer.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Relatively straightforward once you have a residence permit and a BSN (citizen service number). Difficult without them.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Efficient and highly digitized, but very strict and rule-based. Key initial steps are registering your address at the local municipality (gemeente) to get a BSN and registering your business at the Chamber of Commerce (KvK).
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of IND and expat reporting.

visas.bonuses_incentives: Low living costs.
visas.remarks: ‚è≥ Program has been announced but official requirements and a launch date have not been confirmed. Details are subject to change.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: Announced but not yet implemented as of mid-2025. Details remain unconfirmed.
legal_pathways.self_employment: Residency can be obtained by registering a local company (DOO or DOOEL) and then applying for a C-type visa and temporary residence permit. This is a complex process intended for those serving the local market.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: A 'Citizenship by Investment' program exists, requiring a significant donation or investment (e.g., ‚Ç¨200,000) for an expedited citizenship path.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: A 10% flat rate on employment income, business income, and most other forms of personal income.
tax_system.special_regimes: No specific regimes for nomads or expats, but the flat tax is already very competitive.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Non-residents are taxed at 10% only on income sourced from North Macedonia.

contribution_rates.employed: Contributions are high. The employee pays 19.1% and the employer pays 12.1% of the gross salary (total of 31.2%).
contribution_rates.self_employed: Freelancers registered locally must pay the full social security contributions themselves.

benefits.healthcare: Residents who contribute have access to the public healthcare system.
benefits.pension: Contributory state pension system for residents.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Information for the unlaunched nomad visa is not available. Standard long-term visa processes are considered moderately complex and slow, requiring applications to be submitted at an embassy abroad.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Relatively straightforward to open with a passport and proof of residence.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The system can be bureaucratic and may require the use of local legal or administrative assistance. The Cyrillic alphabet and language barrier can be challenging outside of Skopje.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of available information.

visas.bonuses_incentives: High standard of living, beautiful nature.

cost_of_living.overall_index: Extremely high, among world's most expensive

visas.remarks: üá≥üá¥ This visa is for self-employed individuals with a registered business abroad who have a contract to perform work for a Norwegian client. It is not a true 'work from anywhere' visa. Requires an annual income of at least NOK 385,815 (~‚Ç¨35,719).

visas.family_inclusion: Yes (if they can also support themselves)
visas.bonuses_incentives: Unique Arctic experience, low tax.
visas.remarks: üêª‚Äç‚ùÑÔ∏è Not a visa program; a unique treaty allows visa-free residency. You must prove you have sufficient funds to support yourself and secure housing before arrival. Entry via mainland Norway may require a separate Schengen visa.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: Mainland Norway offers a residence permit for self-employed persons with a business abroad who have a contract with a Norwegian entity. Svalbard is visa-free for all nationalities due to the Svalbard Treaty, but requires proof of self-sufficiency.
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is the basis for the mainland Norway permit. It is not for remote work for non-Norwegian clients.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: Norway does not offer a formal residency-by-investment or 'Golden Visa' program.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Mainland: A combined flat tax (22%) and a progressive surtax on gross income result in total rates from 22% up to ~47.4% for high earners. Svalbard: A simplified, much lower system with a flat rate of 8% on low incomes and 22% on higher incomes.
tax_system.special_regimes: The PAYE (Pay As You Earn) scheme offers a flat 25% tax rate for the first year for certain foreign workers on the mainland, but this typically applies to employees, not freelancers.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Non-residents are taxed only on Norwegian-source income.

contribution_rates.employed: Mainland: Employee pays 7.8% of gross salary; Employer pays up to 14.1%. Svalbard: The rates are significantly lower.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Mainland: Freelancers pay a high contribution of 11.0% of their business income.

benefits.healthcare: Residents contributing to the National Insurance Scheme (folketrygden) have access to Norway's excellent public healthcare system. This applies on the mainland and to a limited extent in Svalbard.
benefits.pension: Comprehensive state pension system for residents.

bureaucracy.visa_process: High complexity for the mainland visa. Applications are handled by the Norwegian Directorate of Immigration (UDI) and require extensive documentation. Processing can take several months. Svalbard has no visa process, but the Governor (Sysselmesteren) can expel anyone without sufficient funds.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Difficult. Requires a Norwegian National ID number, which you only get after your residence permit is approved and you register.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Efficient, modern, and highly digital, but very rule-based and inflexible. Procedures must be followed exactly. English proficiency is very high across all sectors.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of UDI guidelines and expat reporting.

visas.visa_length: 4-month visa, converted to a 2-year residence permit, renewable up to 5 years
visas.bonuses_incentives: Schengen access, path to permanent residency and citizenship.
visas.remarks: üáµüáπ Very popular option with a clear path to residency. Income requirement is 4x the Portuguese minimum wage (‚Ç¨870 in 2025, so ‚Ç¨3,480/month). Process can be very slow (6-18 months) due to backlogs at the AIMA immigration agency.

visas.visa_length: 4-month visa, converted to a 2-year residence permit, renewable
visas.bonuses_incentives: Healthcare and Schengen access; path to permanent residency.
visas.remarks: üí∞ For those with passive income (pensions, rent, dividends), not active remote work. Lower income requirement than the D8 visa (1x minimum wage, ‚Ç¨870/month in 2025). A good alternative for retirees or investors.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The D8 Visa is available for remote workers. Requires income of 4x the Portuguese minimum wage (~‚Ç¨3,480/month).
legal_pathways.self_employment: The D2 Visa is for entrepreneurs who wish to open a business in Portugal, requiring a solid business plan and investment.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: The Golden Visa program exists, but no longer for real estate. It requires investment in funds or cultural heritage starting from ‚Ç¨250,000.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Progressive rates (IRS) from 13% to 48% for tax residents. Non-residents pay a flat rate of 25% on Portuguese-source income.
tax_system.special_regimes: The Non-Habitual Resident (NHR) regime has ended. It was replaced in 2024 by the 'Incentivised Tax Status' (ITS) for specific professions (e.g., higher education teachers, scientific researchers), offering a 20% flat tax rate for 10 years. This new regime is much more restrictive and does not apply to most digital nomads.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Individuals are generally tax resident if they stay over 183 days in a 12-month period, making them liable for tax on worldwide income.

contribution_rates.employed: Employee pays 11%; employer pays 23.75%.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Freelancers ('Trabalhadores Independentes') are exempt for the first 12 months. Afterwards, the standard rate is 21.4% on a determined portion of their income.

benefits.healthcare: Upon registering as a resident and getting a social security number (NISS), individuals have access to the National Health Service (SNS).
benefits.pension: Contributions build entitlement to the state pension.
benefits.unemployment: Coverage is primarily for those who have lost traditional employment.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Very high complexity and long delays. Applications are submitted to the consulate, but the main challenge is the mandatory in-person residency permit appointment with the AIMA agency in Portugal, which has a backlog of over 400,000 cases. Wait times of 12-18+ months are common.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Relatively easy. Requires a passport and a Portuguese tax number (NIF), which can be obtained remotely through a representative before arrival.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Considered highly bureaucratic. The transition from the SEF to AIMA immigration agency has created significant bottlenecks. Getting a NIF is the easy first step; every subsequent step is known to be slow and document-intensive.
bureaucracy.source: https://advocateabroad.com/portugal/relocation-to-portugal/

visas.bonuses_incentives: Families allowed.
visas.remarks: üßõ Low cost of living and fast internet speeds. Income requirement is 3x the average Romanian gross salary (approx. ‚Ç¨3,300/month). Can be applied for online or at an embassy.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: Available for non-EU nationals. Requires proof of remote work for a foreign entity for at least 3 years prior and an income of 3x the average gross salary in Romania.
legal_pathways.self_employment: A long-stay visa for economic activities is available for those who register as a PFA (authorized physical person) or set up a company (SRL), but this is more complex than the nomad visa.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: No specific investment visa, but residency can be obtained through establishing and running a significant business.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: A 10% flat rate on most types of income. Digital nomads are exempt from this tax if they do not become a tax resident (stay <183 days).
tax_system.special_regimes: For resident freelancers (PFA), there is a simplified 'norma de venit' system for certain professions, where tax is paid on a fixed annual amount set by the government, regardless of actual income. This can be highly advantageous.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: If tax residency is established, worldwide income is generally taxed at 10%.

contribution_rates.employed: Employee pays 25% for social insurance (CAS) and 10% for health insurance (CASS). Employer pays a 2.25% work insurance contribution.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Resident freelancers (PFA) must pay 25% (CAS) and 10% (CASS) on their real income if it exceeds certain annual thresholds (12 or 24 national minimum gross salaries).

benefits.healthcare: Digital nomad visa holders must have private health insurance for the duration of their visa. Residents who contribute to CASS have access to the public medical system.
benefits.pension: Contributions to CAS build entitlement to the state pension.
benefits.unemployment: Coverage is primarily for those who have lost traditional employment.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity. The application can be submitted online through the eVisa portal, but applicants must then visit a Romanian consulate for an interview. After arrival, a separate application for the residence permit must be filed with the General Inspectorate for Immigration (IGI).
bureaucracy.bank_account: Relatively straightforward. Most banks will open an account for a foreigner with a valid passport and sometimes proof of address.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Can be quite bureaucratic and slow, with a strong emphasis on paper documents, stamps, and in-person visits. Patience and a good sense of humor are beneficial. The language barrier can be an issue at official offices.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official guidelines and expat reporting.

visas.visa_name: Temporary Residence on Grounds of Employment/Self-Employment
visas.bonuses_incentives: Tax-free first 90 days for some.
visas.remarks: ‚è≥ A specific digital nomad visa has been announced but is not yet fully implemented. The current route is to register as a sole proprietor (preduzetnik) and apply for temporary residence based on self-employment. The application is now digital.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: Announced but not yet implemented as a distinct category. Foreign Minister announced visa modernization and an e-Visa system in June 2025, but specifics are pending.
legal_pathways.self_employment: The most common route for nomads. Involves registering as a sole proprietor ('preduzetnik') in Serbia and then applying for a temporary residence permit based on that registration. This can now be done via a unified online portal.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: No formal investment visa, but residency is tied to establishing a business (d.o.o. company) and employing oneself as the director.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: A 10% flat rate on employment income. For freelancers, a favorable 'lump-sum' (pau≈°al) tax system is available.
tax_system.special_regimes: The lump-sum (pau≈°al) system allows freelancers in specific fields (like IT) to pay a fixed monthly amount that covers all taxes and social contributions, regardless of actual income (up to an annual revenue limit of 6 million RSD). This amount is determined by the government based on profession and location.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Non-residents are taxed only on Serbian-source income.

contribution_rates.employed: Employee pays 19.9%; employer pays ~15.15% of gross salary.
contribution_rates.self_employed: For lump-sum taxpayers, the fixed monthly payment includes all social security (pension, health, unemployment). For other freelancers, contributions are ~35% of a determined tax base.

benefits.healthcare: Registering as a sole proprietor and paying contributions grants access to the public healthcare system.
benefits.pension: Contributions build entitlement to the state pension.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate to high complexity. While a unified online portal was launched, the process of registering a business and then applying for residency still has many steps. Required documents (e.g., proof of address via a 'white card') can be tricky. Processing times can be several weeks to months.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Relatively straightforward to open with a passport. Business accounts require the company registration documents.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The system is becoming more digitized but remains bureaucratic. The language barrier can be an issue, and using a local agency or accountant for the initial setup is very common and recommended.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official guidelines and expat reporting.

visas.visa_length: Initial 1 year (if applying from abroad) or 3 years (if applying in Spain); renew up to 5 years
visas.bonuses_incentives: Special tax regime, family inclusion, path to long-term residency.
visas.remarks: üá™üá∏ Path to long-term residency and special tax regime. Income requirement: 200% of Spain's Minimum Interprofessional Salary (SMI), approx. ‚Ç¨2,640/month in 2025. Up to 20% of income can come from Spanish clients. Can be applied for in Spain or at a consulate.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The 'International Teleworking Visa' is available for non-EU nationals. Can be applied for from abroad (1-year visa) or within Spain (3-year permit). Requires an income of 200% of the national minimum wage.
legal_pathways.self_employment: A 'Self-Employed Work Visa' is a separate, more complex category requiring a detailed business plan to be approved by a relevant Spanish authority (e.g., UATAE).
legal_pathways.investment_visa: The 'Golden Visa' program was modified in 2024 to remove the real estate investment option. Other investment pathways (e.g., in government debt or company shares) still exist but are less common.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Progressive rates (IRPF) from 19% to 47%.
tax_system.special_regimes: Digital nomad visa holders can opt into the 'Beckham Law', a special tax regime. This allows them to be taxed as non-residents, paying a flat 24% tax rate on Spanish-source income up to ‚Ç¨600,000 for up to six years. Most foreign-source income is not taxed under this regime.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: This is the basis of the Beckham Law. For those not under the special regime, tax residency (staying >183 days) means being taxed on worldwide income at progressive rates.

contribution_rates.employed: If employed by a foreign company, the company must register in Spain and contribute ~30% of the employee's salary, while the employee contributes ~6.4%. This is complex. Alternatively, the nomad can register as a freelancer ('aut√≥nomo').
contribution_rates.self_employed: Freelancers ('aut√≥nomos') pay monthly contributions based on their real net income, with rates in 2025 ranging from a minimum of ~‚Ç¨220/month for low earners to over ‚Ç¨550/month for high earners. There is an initial flat rate of ‚Ç¨80/month for the first 12 months.

benefits.healthcare: Paying social security contributions grants access to Spain's excellent public healthcare system.
benefits.pension: Contributions build entitlement to the state pension.
benefits.unemployment: Aut√≥nomos can pay an additional premium for access to unemployment benefits ('paro por cese de actividad').

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate to high complexity. Applying from within Spain is generally faster (20-45 days). The key is gathering extensive, correctly formatted documentation. After approval, you must apply for a TIE (Foreigner Identity Card), which requires a separate appointment and process.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Can be opened as a non-resident with a passport and NIE (foreign tax number), but full-featured resident accounts require the TIE card.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Spanish bureaucracy is known to be slow and requires in-person appointments for most steps (TIE, town hall registration 'padr√≥n'). The system is fragmented, and getting appointments can be a major challenge due to high demand.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official procedures and extensive expat reporting.

visas.visa_length: Initial 12 months; extensions depend on canton
visas.bonuses_incentives: High quality of life.
visas.remarks: üèîÔ∏è Extremely difficult to obtain for non-EU citizens. No digital nomad visa exists. This permit requires proving your new business serves a Swiss economic interest, creating jobs, and that you have sufficient funds. Approval is decided at the cantonal level and is very rare.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: Switzerland does not offer a digital nomad visa.
legal_pathways.self_employment: Non-EU nationals can apply for a residence permit (B Permit) for self-employment. This is extremely difficult to get, as it requires a comprehensive business plan proving the business will have a 'lasting positive effect on the Swiss labour market' (e.g., job creation, innovation). Approval is at the discretion of the canton.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: There is no formal investment visa, but high-net-worth individuals can sometimes negotiate residency with a canton based on 'significant cantonal fiscal interest', which involves paying a substantial lump-sum annual tax.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Highly complex system with taxes levied at three levels: federal, cantonal, and municipal. Federal tax is progressive up to 11.5%. Cantonal/municipal taxes vary hugely, leading to overall top marginal rates ranging from ~22% (in Zug) to ~45% (in Geneva).
tax_system.special_regimes: 'Lump-sum taxation' is an option for wealthy foreign residents who are not gainfully employed in Switzerland. They pay a fixed annual tax based on their living expenses, not their actual income or wealth.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Non-residents are taxed at source on Swiss-based income, such as employment.

contribution_rates.employed: The total rate for Old-Age and Survivors' Insurance (AHV/AVS), Disability Insurance (IV/AI), and Income Loss Insurance (EO/APG) is 10.6%. This is split equally, with the employee paying 5.3% and the employer paying 5.3%. Additional contributions apply for unemployment and pension.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Freelancers pay the full contribution themselves, with a rate of up to 10% on their business income, plus administrative costs. Contributions are mandatory.

benefits.healthcare: Mandatory private health insurance system (KVG/LaMal). All residents must purchase a basic policy within three months of arrival. The system is high-quality but very expensive.
benefits.pension: A robust three-pillar system: 1st (state AHV), 2nd (mandatory occupational pension for employees), and 3rd (voluntary private pension).
benefits.unemployment: Comprehensive benefits for employees who have contributed.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Extremely high complexity for non-EU self-employment. The process is long (often 6+ months), expensive, and has a very low chance of success. It requires extensive documentation and justification.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Can be difficult for non-residents, especially from certain countries (e.g., US citizens due to FATCA). Requires significant paperwork and often a minimum deposit. Once residency is established, it becomes easier.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Processes are famously efficient, well-organized, and punctual, but also extremely rigid and rule-based. Deadlines are strict, and paperwork must be perfect. Dealing with cantonal authorities is a key part of life.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official SEM guidelines and expat reporting.

visas.bonuses_incentives: No income proof; path to permanent residency.
visas.remarks: üá¶üá≤ Path to residency by registering as a sole proprietor (Individual Entrepreneur). No explicit income requirement. Most nomads enter visa-free (for up to 180 days), register the business, then apply for the residence permit in-country. After 3 years of residency, you can apply for citizenship (requires a language/civics test).

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: Armenia does not have a specific digital nomad visa. The common pathway is to use the visa-free entry (up to 180 days for many nationalities), register as a Sole Proprietor (Individual Entrepreneur), and then apply for a temporary residence permit on that basis.
legal_pathways.self_employment: Registering as a Sole Proprietor is a straightforward process that can be completed in a few days at the State Register of Legal Entities.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: Residency can be obtained by investing in real estate or establishing a local business, although the Sole Proprietor route is simpler and more common for freelancers.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: A 20% flat rate on employment and other personal income.
tax_system.special_regimes: The most attractive regime is the 'Turnover Tax', available to Sole Proprietors with annual revenue below 115 million AMD (~$295,000). For many service-based activities, including IT consulting and programming, the tax rate on turnover is just 5%. Some specific IT activities may even qualify for a 0% rate.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Non-residents are taxed at 10% or 20% on Armenian-source income, depending on the type.

contribution_rates.employed: The employee pays 5% of their monthly gross salary (capped at AMD 75,000/month) and the employer contributes a flat monthly social payment per employee.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Sole Proprietors registered under the Turnover Tax regime are generally exempt from making separate social security contributions. Their tax payment covers their obligations.

benefits.healthcare: A basic public healthcare system exists but is considered underfunded. All residents, including foreigners with permits, must have health insurance, which is often private.
benefits.pension: A mandatory funded pension system exists for employees, where the 5% social payment is directed.

bureaucracy.visa_process: The residency permit process (post-business registration) is moderately complex. It is handled by the Passport and Visa Department of the Police. Applications must be submitted in person and can take 30-45 days.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Relatively easy to open with a passport and its notarized Armenian translation. Opening an account is a prerequisite for business registration.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Registering a business is very efficient and can be done quickly. However, subsequent administrative tasks (like residency application) can be more bureaucratic. The language barrier can be a significant issue in government offices, and using a local representative is common.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official guidelines and expat reporting.

visas.visa_length: Initially 30 days, can be extended for 1, 3, 6, or 12 months
visas.bonuses_incentives: Easy to obtain and extend long-term.
visas.remarks: üá∞üá≠ This is the de facto long-term visa for nomads. You request an E-class visa on arrival (do not get the T-class tourist visa). Before the initial 30 days are up, you use a visa agent to get an EB (Business) extension for 6 or 12 months. A local work permit is technically required for the EB extension but is often unenforced for freelancers working for foreign clients, though this is a grey area.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: Cambodia does not have an official digital nomad visa. The standard pathway is the renewable Ordinary (E-Class) visa, typically with an 'EB' (Business) extension.
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the EB extension. While technically for those employed by a Cambodian entity, it is widely used by freelancers and remote workers.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: An 'EI' (Investor) visa extension is available for those who have invested in a registered Cambodian business, but the EB visa is more common.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: For tax residents (in Cambodia >182 days), a progressive Tax on Salary (ToS) applies, ranging from 0% up to 20%. The 20% bracket applies to monthly income over KHR 12,500,000 (~$3,000).
tax_system.special_regimes: No specific regimes for nomads. The primary benefit is the generally low tax rates.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Non-residents are taxed at a flat rate of 20% on their Cambodian-sourced income. Most nomads on E-visas fall into the resident category after 182 days.

contribution_rates.employed: For employees of registered Cambodian companies, contributions to the National Social Security Fund (NSSF) are mandatory. The employee contributes 2% for pension, and the employer contributes 0.8% for occupational risk and 2% for pension.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Freelancers and remote workers for foreign companies are generally not required to register or contribute to the NSSF.

benefits.healthcare: NSSF contributors have access to a basic public health scheme. Most expats and nomads rely exclusively on private health insurance and use private clinics and hospitals.
benefits.pension: A state pension system exists for contributing formal employees.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Very easy initial entry (visa on arrival). Extensions are also very easy but are almost exclusively handled by local visa agencies for a fee, rather than by applying directly at the immigration department. The process is fast (a few days to a week).
bureaucracy.bank_account: Relatively straightforward. Most major banks (like ABA, Acleda) will open an account for foreigners with a passport, a 6-month or 1-year visa, and sometimes proof of address.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Day-to-day life is relatively free of bureaucracy. However, official processes like work permits or business registration are complex and best handled by local agents. The visa system's reliance on agents creates a simplified but unofficial bureaucratic layer.
bureaucracy.source: https://www.bank-cambodia.org/how-to-open-a-bank-account-in-cambodia-as-a-foreigner-a-complete-guide

visas.visa_length: Up to 5 years (90 or 180-day limit per visit depending on nationality)
visas.eligible_citizens: Citizens of eligible countries for e-Visa
visas.bonuses_incentives: Low cost of living.
visas.remarks: ‚ö†Ô∏è Alternative Pathway: Remote work is officially not permitted on a Tourist Visa. Stays are limited to 90 or 180 consecutive days, requiring a 'visa run'. There is no official digital nomad visa. Anyone staying over 180 days must register with the FRRO.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: India does not offer a digital nomad visa. Working on a tourist visa is a violation of visa rules, though it is a common practice for short-term visitors.
legal_pathways.self_employment: Requires obtaining an Employment Visa, which is difficult. The sponsoring Indian company must justify why a foreign national is needed, and the applicant must earn a minimum salary of $25,000 USD per year.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: A Business Visa is available for those looking to establish an industrial/business venture in India, but it does not permit full-time employment.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Under the (default) New Tax Regime for FY 2024-25, income is taxed progressively: 0% up to ‚Çπ3 lakh; 5% up to ‚Çπ6 lakh; 10% up to ‚Çπ9 lakh; 15% up to ‚Çπ12 lakh; 20% up to ‚Çπ15 lakh; and 30% above ‚Çπ15 lakh.
tax_system.special_regimes: A presumptive taxation scheme (Section 44ADA) is available for certain resident professionals (freelancers), where 50% of gross receipts are considered profit and taxed accordingly, simplifying accounting.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: An individual becomes a tax resident if they stay in India for 182 days or more in a financial year. Once a tax resident, they are taxed on their global income.

contribution_rates.employed: Mandatory for employees of registered Indian companies. The employee contributes 12% to the Provident Fund (PF), and the employer contributes a matching amount.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Foreign freelancers are not part of the system. International Workers from countries without a Social Security Agreement with India may be required to contribute to PF if they take up formal employment.

benefits.healthcare: A public healthcare system exists but is severely under-resourced. Most expats and remote workers rely exclusively on private hospitals and clinics, for which private health insurance is essential.
benefits.pension: A pension scheme (EPS) is part of the Provident Fund for formal employees.
benefits.unemployment: No state unemployment benefits for freelancers or foreign workers.

bureaucracy.visa_process: e-Visa application is online and relatively efficient. However, any process beyond that is highly bureaucratic. Any foreign national staying over 180 days must register with the Foreigners' Regional Registration Office (FRRO), a complex and often frustrating process.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Difficult to open without local residency proof (like a rental agreement) and a PAN card (tax number). A tourist visa is generally not sufficient to open a full-service bank account.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Considered highly bureaucratic. Processes are slow, require extensive paperwork in multiple copies, and can be opaque. Dealing with any government office can be a significant challenge.
bureaucracy.source: https://www.indiafilings.com/learn/frro-registration-process/

visas.bonuses_incentives: Tax-free on foreign income if requirements are met.
visas.remarks: üå¥ This visa, officially a form of KITAS (limited stay permit), is for remote workers. Requires proof of $60,000/year income. Crucially, it exempts holders from paying Indonesian tax on income sourced from outside Indonesia. This is the official replacement for the previous grey-area visa runs.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The E33G Remote Worker Visa is the official visa for this purpose. It grants a 1-year KITAS (temporary residency permit).
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the E33G visa for work with foreign clients. Working for Indonesian clients requires a different, more complex work permit.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: An Investor KITAS is available for those who make a significant investment in establishing a local company (PMA). The 'Second Home Visa' is for wealthy individuals who deposit IDR 2 billion (~$125,000) in a state-owned bank.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Holders of the E33G remote worker visa are exempt from Indonesian tax on their foreign-sourced income. If an individual stays over 183 days without this specific visa (e.g., on an Investor KITAS), they become a tax resident and are taxed on worldwide income at progressive rates from 5% to 35%.
tax_system.special_regimes: The tax exemption for foreign-sourced income is the key special regime for E33G visa holders.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Non-residents are taxed at a flat 20% rate on any income sourced from within Indonesia.

contribution_rates.employed: If formally employed by an Indonesian company, contributions to BPJS Ketenagakerjaan (social security) and BPJS Kesehatan (health) are mandatory.
contribution_rates.self_employed: E33G visa holders are not required to contribute to the Indonesian social security system.

benefits.healthcare: It is mandatory for all foreigners residing in Indonesia for more than six months to have health insurance. E33G visa holders must show proof of private insurance; they do not access the public BPJS system.
benefits.pension: No access to the state pension system for E33G visa holders.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity. The application is done online via a licensed agent or sponsor. After the e-visa is approved, the applicant travels to Indonesia and must visit an immigration office within 90 days for biometric data collection to convert the visa into a KITAS card. The process takes 3-4 weeks.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Relatively straightforward to open once you have the KITAS. It is very difficult to open an account without a KITAS or KITAP (permanent residency).
bureaucracy.general_admin: Typical Southeast Asian bureaucracy. While online systems are improving, processes can be slow and require the use of local agents or sponsors for almost all immigration matters. The agent system is a core part of the bureaucracy.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official guidelines and agent websites.

visas.eligible_citizens: Nationals of 49 countries with tax treaties and visa-free agreements with Japan (including USA, UK, Australia, Singapore, and most EU countries).
visas.bonuses_incentives: Exempt from Japanese income tax on foreign earnings.
visas.remarks: üáØüáµ Short-term visa for specific nationalities. Income requirement is ¬•10 million/year (~$63,000 USD). Cannot be renewed; must leave Japan for 6 months before reapplying. Visa holders are not issued a Residence Card, which limits access to some services like opening a bank account or signing long-term leases. Must apply in person at a Japanese embassy or consulate.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The 'Specified visa: Digital Nomad' is available for citizens of 49 eligible countries with an annual income of at least ¬•10 million.
legal_pathways.self_employment: The 'Business Manager' visa is for those establishing a physical office and company in Japan, a much more complex and expensive process.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: This is covered by the Business Manager visa, which requires a capital investment of at least ¬•5 million (~$32,000).

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Holders of the Digital Nomad visa are not considered tax residents and are therefore not subject to Japanese income tax on their foreign-sourced income.
tax_system.special_regimes: The tax exemption is the key feature of this visa status.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Not applicable to digital nomad visa holders on their foreign income.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable. Visa holders are not permitted to be employed by a Japanese company.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Not applicable. Digital Nomad visa holders are not required to enroll or contribute to the Japanese social security or pension systems.

benefits.healthcare: It is a mandatory requirement for the visa to have private health insurance with a minimum coverage of ¬•10 million for the entire duration of the stay. Visa holders do not access the National Health Insurance (NHI) system.
benefits.pension: No access to the Japanese pension system.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity. Requires precise documentation (proof of income, insurance policy details) to be submitted in person at a Japanese embassy. Processing is relatively fast, typically a few weeks.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Difficult. As visa holders are not issued a Residence Card, they generally cannot open a traditional Japanese bank account. They must rely on international banking solutions or credit cards.
bureaucracy.general_admin: While the visa process is clear, the limitations of not having a Residence Card create administrative hurdles for long-term living arrangements (e.g., standard apartment leases, mobile phone contracts).
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official guidelines and expat reporting.

visas.bonuses_incentives: Multicultural society; strategic Asia location; tax exemption.
visas.remarks: üá≤üáæ Low income requirement ($24,000/year) and straightforward online process. An additional fee of RM 500 (~$110) applies for each dependent. Tax-exempt on foreign-sourced income.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The 'DE Rantau Nomad Pass' is available for digital professionals (IT, digital marketing, content creation etc.) with an annual income of at least $24,000 USD (for freelancers) or $60,000 USD (for remote employees).
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the DE Rantau Pass for freelancers and independent contractors serving foreign clients.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: The 'Malaysia My Second Home (MM2H)' program is a long-term visa for wealthy foreigners, but its requirements (high fixed deposits, income) have become much stricter recently.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Holders of the DE Rantau Nomad Pass are exempt from paying Malaysian income tax on income sourced from outside of Malaysia.
tax_system.special_regimes: The tax exemption is the primary benefit. For other residents, a progressive tax system applies with rates from 0% to 30%.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Malaysia generally operates a territorial tax system, meaning only income derived from Malaysia is taxed. The DE Rantau pass formalizes this exemption for pass holders.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable to pass holders working for foreign companies.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Holders of the DE Rantau Nomad Pass are not required to contribute to the Employees Provident Fund (EPF) or Social Security Organisation (SOCSO).

benefits.healthcare: It is a mandatory requirement to have valid medical insurance covering your stay in Malaysia. Pass holders do not access the public healthcare system.
benefits.pension: No access to the Malaysian pension system (EPF).

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity, handled entirely online. Requires extensive document uploads (CV, contracts, bank statements). Processing time is officially 4-6 weeks but can sometimes take longer. After approval, the pass must be endorsed in your passport in Malaysia.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Can be opened with the DE Rantau Pass approval letter and passport. Some banks may have additional requirements, but it is generally feasible.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The process is well-defined through the MDEC portal. Outside of that, Malaysia has moderate bureaucracy, but the widespread use of English simplifies many interactions.
bureaucracy.source: https://www.malaysiavisas.com/digital-nomad-visa-de-rantau/

visas.bonuses_incentives: Exempt from income tax on foreign earnings.
visas.remarks: ‚úÖ Officially approved via Executive Order in April 2025, with implementation starting from June 23, 2025. An annual income of at least $24,000 is expected. Full application procedures are being finalized and will likely be available through the e-visa portal. This provides a legal basis for remote work.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: A new Digital Nomad Visa was officially created by Executive Order in April 2025. The program is set to launch from June 23, 2025. It will allow a one-year stay, renewable for another year.
legal_pathways.self_employment: This will be covered by the new Digital Nomad Visa. Previously, there was no clear pathway for foreign freelancers.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: The 'Special Investor's Resident Visa' (SIRV) is available for those making a large investment (at least $75,000 USD) in eligible domestic businesses.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Holders of the new Digital Nomad Visa will be exempt from Philippine income tax on their income generated from foreign sources.
tax_system.special_regimes: The tax exemption is the key feature. For other residents, a progressive tax system applies with rates up to 35%.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: The visa is specifically designed to treat holders as non-residents for tax purposes regarding their foreign income.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable to DNV holders.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Digital Nomad Visa holders are not expected to be required to contribute to the local Social Security System (SSS) or PhilHealth.

benefits.healthcare: It will be a mandatory requirement for the visa to have valid private/international health insurance. DNV holders will not access the public PhilHealth system.
benefits.pension: No access to the Philippine pension system.

bureaucracy.visa_process: The full process is still being finalized. It is expected to be managed online via the e-visa portal, with final applications made at a Philippine consulate abroad. After arrival, obtaining the Alien Certificate of Registration (ACR I-Card) will be a mandatory step.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Difficult without long-term residency status and an ACR I-Card. It is unclear if the new visa will simplify this process.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Philippine bureaucracy is known to be slow, paper-based, and challenging to navigate. Using a local agent or 'fixer' for administrative tasks is a very common practice.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of current processes and news about the new visa.

visas.bonuses_incentives: Cannot work for a local company.
visas.remarks: üá∞üá∑ High-tech infrastructure and vibrant culture. Income requirement is double South Korea's previous year GNI per capita (KRW 84.96 million/year for 2024 applicants, approx. ~$62,000 USD). Application must be done in person at a Korean embassy. Within 90 days of arrival, must apply for an Alien Registration Card (ARC).

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The 'Workation' (F-1-D) visa is available for remote workers with an income of at least twice the South Korean GNI per capita from the previous year.
legal_pathways.self_employment: A D-8 Corporate Investment visa is available for those who establish a corporation in Korea with a significant capital investment.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: This is covered by the D-8 visa.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: If a Workation visa holder stays for 183 days or more in a calendar year, they become a tax resident and are subject to tax on their worldwide income. Progressive rates range from 6% to 45%.
tax_system.special_regimes: No special tax regimes exist for digital nomads. Standard tax laws apply upon becoming a tax resident.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: If staying less than 183 days, you are a non-resident and only taxed on Korean-sourced income (which should be zero for a digital nomad).

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable to DNV holders.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Foreign residents staying over six months are generally required to enroll in the National Health Insurance (NHI) program. However, it may be possible to apply for an exemption if you can prove you have equivalent private international health insurance.

benefits.healthcare: A visa requirement is to have private health insurance with at least KRW 100 million (~$75,000) in coverage. If you become a resident for over 6 months and enroll in the NHI, you gain access to the excellent public system.
benefits.pension: No access to the Korean pension system for DNV holders.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity. Application must be submitted in person at a South Korean embassy. Requires proof of income, employment, and a clean criminal record. Processing can take from 2 weeks to 2 months. After arrival, applying for the Alien Registration Card (ARC) is a mandatory and separate step.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Difficult to open without an Alien Registration Card (ARC). Once you have the ARC, the process is straightforward.
