bureaucracy.general_admin: The system is highly digitized and efficient, but can be rigid. An ARC is essential for most administrative tasks (phone contracts, online services). Language can be a barrier in some government offices.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official guidelines and expat reporting.

visas.visa_length: Up to 10 years (with a 180-day stay limit per year)
visas.bonuses_incentives: Low cost of living, beautiful scenery.
visas.remarks: ‚è≥ While a dedicated digital nomad visa has been discussed, it has not been implemented. Instead, as of April 2024, Sri Lanka introduced new long-term tourist e-visas (2, 5, and 10-year options) that allow stays of up to 180 days per year, making it a viable long-stay destination for nomads. Working remotely is a grey area but generally tolerated.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: No specific digital nomad visa exists. The government has introduced new long-term tourist visa options (up to 10 years with a 180-day per year stay limit) that facilitate longer stays.
legal_pathways.self_employment: Requires obtaining a residence visa through company formation, which is a more complex process intended for those investing in the local economy.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: Residence visas are available for investors who remit a significant amount of foreign currency to be invested in a local business or deposited in a Sri Lankan bank.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: An individual becomes tax resident if they are in Sri Lanka for 183 days or more. As of April 2025, resident income is taxed progressively from 6% to 36%. The top rate of 36% applies to annual income over LKR 2.5 million (~$8,200).
tax_system.special_regimes: A key benefit is that income received in foreign currency from services rendered outside Sri Lanka and remitted through a bank is taxed at a concessionary rate of 15%.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Non-residents are taxed only on income sourced from Sri Lanka.

contribution_rates.employed: For local employment, the employee contributes 8% to the Employees' Provident Fund (EPF) and the employer contributes 12% (EPF) plus 3% to the Employees' Trust Fund (ETF).
contribution_rates.self_employed: This system does not apply to foreign freelancers or remote workers for foreign companies.

benefits.healthcare: A public healthcare system exists but most expats use private clinics and hospitals, for which private insurance is essential.
benefits.pension: The EPF/ETF system is for local employees.
benefits.unemployment: No unemployment benefits for foreign workers.

bureaucracy.visa_process: The new e-visa system is online and relatively straightforward for tourist visas. However, extending a stay beyond the initial period requires an in-person application at the Department of Immigration & Emigration in Colombo, which can be bureaucratic.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Difficult for non-residents. Opening an account typically requires a residence visa, proof of address, and sometimes a letter of introduction.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Bureaucracy can be slow and requires patience. Processes often require physical paperwork and in-person visits. Using local agents for services is common.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official guidelines and expat reporting.

visas.bonuses_incentives: Tax benefits, open work rights, path to permanent residency.
visas.remarks: üíº For highly skilled professionals, not a simple nomad visa. Requires proving expertise in specific fields (e.g., Science, Technology, Economy). One of the main qualification criteria is having a past monthly salary of at least NT$160,000 (~$5,200). Offers open work rights and a path to residency.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The 'Employment Gold Card' is Taiwan's de facto visa for highly skilled remote workers and freelancers. It's a 4-in-1 card that includes a work permit, resident visa, Alien Resident Certificate (ARC), and re-entry permit.
legal_pathways.self_employment: The Gold Card grants open work rights, meaning holders can work for any company (or multiple companies), or be self-employed without needing separate permits.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: An Entrepreneur Visa exists but is more complex and requires setting up a business and meeting innovation criteria. The Gold Card is generally a better option for skilled individuals.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Progressive rates from 5% to 40%.
tax_system.special_regimes: For the first five years of being a tax resident (staying >183 days), Gold Card holders with an annual salary over NT$3 million are only taxed on 50% of the income exceeding the NT$3 million mark. Their foreign-sourced income is also exempt from the Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT).
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Non-residents are taxed at a flat rate of 18% on their Taiwan-sourced income.

contribution_rates.employed: Formal employees have contributions withheld by their employer.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Gold Card holders without a formal employer in Taiwan must enroll in the National Health Insurance (NHI) program after residing in Taiwan for six consecutive months.

benefits.healthcare: Upon eligibility (immediately if employed, after 6 months if self-employed), card holders gain access to Taiwan's world-class, affordable National Health Insurance (NHI) system. It is mandatory to enroll once eligible.
benefits.pension: Card holders can opt into the voluntary pension scheme.
benefits.unemployment: Unemployment benefits are tied to local employment.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity, handled entirely online via the Gold Card portal. The main challenge is providing sufficient documentation to prove qualification in one of the specified fields. Processing time is officially 30-60 days but can sometimes be longer depending on the reviewing ministry.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Relatively easy to open with the Gold Card and passport.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Highly efficient and digitized. The Gold Card itself acts as your ARC and re-entry permit, simplifying many processes. The government has a dedicated Gold Card Help Desk to assist applicants and holders, which significantly reduces bureaucratic hurdles.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official Gold Card portal information and user experiences.

visas.bonuses_incentives: Multiple entry, 180-day stays, extendable once per entry for additional 180 days
visas.banking_access: Banks no longer accept DTV for account opening
visas.reporting_requirements: First 90-day report in-person, subsequent reports can be done online
visas.extension_process: One 180-day extension per entry in-country, or exit/re-enter for fresh 180-day stamp (easier option)

cost_of_living.overall_index: Low to medium, 40-60% of Western costs

visas.remarks: üí∞ For high-income professionals and investors. Requires personal income of at least $80k/year or significant investment. A premium option for those seeking long-term stability and tax benefits. The application process is complex.

visas.visa_length: 5 years validity, 180-day stay per entry, extendable once for another 180 days.
visas.bonuses_incentives: No work permit required for remote work.

cost_of_living.overall_index: Low to medium, 40-60% of Western costs

visas.remarks: üéâ Thailand's newest visa for nomads! Allows a 180-day stay, extendable once within the country for another 180 days. Requires proof of ~THB 500,000 (~$13,500) in savings. Much more accessible than the LTR.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The Destination Thailand Visa (DTV) is the primary option for remote workers and nomads. The Long-Term Resident (LTR) visa is an option for very high-income 'Work-From-Thailand Professionals'.
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the DTV for freelancers working with foreign clients.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: The Thailand Elite Visa is a long-term paid visa program offering stays from 5 to 20 years for a high fee, but does not automatically grant work rights. The LTR visa also has an 'investor' category.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Progressive rates from 5% to 35%.
tax_system.special_regimes: A major change in 2024 requires Thai tax residents (anyone staying >180 days) to declare and pay tax on foreign-sourced income that is brought into Thailand. For LTR 'Highly-Skilled Professionals', a flat 17% tax rate applies. Other LTR holders and DTV holders are subject to the standard rule.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Non-residents are only taxed on income sourced from within Thailand.

contribution_rates.employed: For local employment, the rate is 5% for both employee and employer.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Foreigners on DTV or LTR visas are not required to contribute to the Thai social security system.

benefits.healthcare: It is a mandatory requirement for long-stay visas to have health insurance. Most expats use private insurance and hospitals. The public system is accessible but often crowded.
benefits.pension: No access to the Thai pension system for DTV/LTR holders.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity. Applications for DTV and LTR are handled online. However, after arrival, all long-term residents must comply with the TM30 (landlord reporting of foreigner's address) and TM47 (90-day reporting of address to immigration), which adds a layer of recurring bureaucracy.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Can be opened with a long-term visa (like LTR or a one-year DTV extension) and proof of address in Thailand. Difficult to open on a short-term tourist entry.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The system relies on in-person visits for extensions and reporting. While processes are well-established, they can be time-consuming. Using visa agents to handle paperwork is very common.
bureaucracy.source: https://ltr.boi.go.th/page/opening-bank-account-in-thailand.html

visas.eligible_citizens: Nationals of 36 select countries (most of EU, UK, USA, Canada), aged 21-55
visas.bonuses_incentives: Tax benefits for certain professions.
visas.remarks: üáπüá∑ Great option but has restrictions. Eligibility is limited by age (21-55) and nationality. Apply online for a certificate, then visit a consulate with the certificate to finalize the visa. After arrival, must apply for a residence permit.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: A 'Digital Nomad Visa' is available for citizens of 36 eligible countries. It requires a monthly income of $3,000 USD and is for individuals aged 21-55.
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the Digital Nomad visa for work with foreign clients. Establishing a local Turkish company is a separate, more complex path to residency.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: Turkey offers a popular 'Citizenship by Investment' program, primarily through a real estate purchase of at least $400,000 USD.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Progressive rates from 15% to 40%.
tax_system.special_regimes: There is a significant tax exemption for digital nomads providing services from Turkey to clients abroad in specific fields like software development, design, and data analytics. Only 20% of their income is subject to income tax, resulting in a very low effective tax rate.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: If staying less than 183 days, you are not a tax resident. If you become a tax resident, the special regime for nomads can still apply, but professional tax advice is recommended.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable to DNV holders.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Foreigners on residence permits are generally not required to pay into the social security system (SGK/Baƒü-Kur) unless they are formally registered as self-employed in Turkey.

benefits.healthcare: It is a mandatory requirement for the residence permit to have valid private health insurance. DNV holders do not access the public healthcare system unless they opt-in.
benefits.pension: No access to the Turkish pension system.

social_security.source: Claude, based on general residence permit requirements.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate to high complexity. It is a multi-step process: 1) Apply online for a 'Digital Nomad Identification Certificate'. 2) Take this certificate to a Turkish consulate to apply for the actual visa. 3) After arrival, apply for the residence permit at the local Directorate General of Migration Management office.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Can be opened with a passport and a Turkish Tax Identification Number, which is easily obtainable online. It is one of the easier countries for non-residents to open an account.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The system is known to be highly bureaucratic, especially for the residence permit application ('Ikamet'), which requires a specific set of documents and an in-person appointment. Processes can be slow and require patience.
bureaucracy.source: https://ikamet.com/obtaining-turkish-residence-permit/

visas.bonuses_incentives: 0% income tax. Resident ID and access to public services.
visas.remarks: üá¶üá™ Enjoy a 0% income tax rate. The visa applies to all Emirates, not just Dubai. The total cost includes the application fee, medical tests, and Emirates ID issuance. Requires proof of employment or company ownership.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The 'Virtual Work Residence Visa' is available for remote workers and business owners from abroad. It requires a monthly income of at least $3,500 USD.
legal_pathways.self_employment: Freelancers can obtain a freelance permit from one of the many free zones (e.g., GoFreelance from Dubai Media City), which then allows them to apply for a residence visa.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: The 'Golden Visa' offers 5 or 10-year residency for investors, entrepreneurs, and highly skilled professionals who meet high-threshold criteria (e.g., investing AED 2 million in a property).

tax_system.personal_income_tax: There is a 0% tax rate on personal income in the UAE. No income tax is levied on salaries or freelance income.
tax_system.special_regimes: The entire country operates as a special tax regime for personal income.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Not applicable as there is no personal income tax.

contribution_rates.employed: Social security contributions are not required for foreign expatriates.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Not applicable for foreign freelancers.

benefits.healthcare: It is mandatory for all residents to have health insurance. For the remote work visa, applicants must secure their own private health insurance.
benefits.pension: No state pension system for expatriates. Individuals are responsible for their own retirement savings.
benefits.unemployment: An 'Involuntary Loss of Employment' (ILOE) insurance scheme is mandatory for most employees, but its application to remote work visa holders can vary.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity but highly efficient. The application is typically started online. After approval and entry, the applicant must complete a medical fitness test and provide biometrics to receive their Emirates ID, which acts as their residence permit. The process is clear and well-defined.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Straightforward to open once you have your Emirates ID and residence visa. Difficult without them.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Considered very efficient and digitally advanced. Many government services are available through apps and online portals. Processes are fast and transparent compared to many other countries.
bureaucracy.source: https://www.investindubai.gov.ae/en/live-and-work/dubai-banking-guide

visas.eligible_citizens: Citizens of most countries are eligible.
visas.bonuses_incentives: Low cost of living, vibrant nomad community.
visas.remarks: üçú Not a dedicated nomad visa. The 90-day multiple-entry e-visa is the common choice for short-to-medium term stays. For longer stays, 'visa runs' (leaving and re-entering the country on a new e-visa) are common practice, though this is a legal grey area. Remote work for foreign companies is tolerated but not officially sanctioned.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: Vietnam does not currently have an official digital nomad visa. The government is considering proposals for long-term 'Golden Visas' for talent and investors, but no program has been launched as of mid-2025.
legal_pathways.self_employment: The common but unofficial method is using the 90-day e-visa. Obtaining a work permit and Temporary Residence Card (TRC) as a freelancer is exceptionally difficult and not a practical route for most.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: An investor visa (DT1-DT4) is available for foreigners who invest a significant amount (ranging from ~$2,000 to ~$4 million) in a Vietnamese company.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: An individual becomes a tax resident if they reside in Vietnam for 183 days or more in a 12-month period. Residents are taxed on their worldwide income at progressive rates from 5% to 35%.
tax_system.special_regimes: No special regimes exist for remote workers. Standard tax laws apply upon establishing tax residency.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Non-residents are taxed at a flat rate of 20% on their Vietnam-sourced income. As remote work income is sourced from abroad, it is not subject to this tax for non-residents.

contribution_rates.employed: Foreign nationals with a work permit employed by a Vietnamese entity must contribute to social insurance (8%) and health insurance (1.5%). The employer contributes significantly more.
contribution_rates.self_employed: This system does not apply to foreign remote workers on an e-visa.

benefits.healthcare: Foreigners on an e-visa must have private health insurance. The public system is only accessible to those with a Temporary Residence Card and social insurance contributions.
benefits.pension: No access to the pension system for e-visa holders.

bureaucracy.visa_process: The e-visa application is straightforward and done online. However, there is no official extension process. This necessitates 'visa runs' every 90 days, which adds a layer of travel-related bureaucracy and cost.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Very difficult to open on a tourist e-visa. Banks generally require a Temporary Residence Card (TRC) or a work permit.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Day-to-day life is relatively simple, but official processes are bureaucratic. Any interaction with government agencies is challenging without a long-term residence status and local language skills.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official guidelines and expat reporting.

visas.bonuses_incentives: No local income tax.
visas.remarks: üá¶üá¨ Enjoy 0% personal income tax in a Caribbean paradise. Requires annual income of $50,000. Straightforward online application. Fees are tiered: $1,500 for an individual, $2,000 for a couple, and $3,000 for a family of 3+.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The 'Nomad Digital Residence' (NDR) program is available for remote workers with a minimum annual income of $50,000 USD.
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the NDR program for freelancers working with foreign clients.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: A 'Citizenship by Investment' program is available, offering a passport for a minimum contribution of $100,000 to the National Development Fund or a $200,000 real estate purchase.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: There is no personal income tax in Antigua and Barbuda. This applies to all residents, including those on the NDR program.
tax_system.special_regimes: The entire country operates as a tax-free jurisdiction for personal income.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: There is a 25% withholding tax on dividends, interest, and royalties paid to non-residents, but this does not affect the foreign income of NDR holders.

contribution_rates.employed: NDR holders are not required to contribute to the local social security scheme.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Not applicable to NDR holders.

benefits.healthcare: It is a mandatory requirement for the NDR visa to have comprehensive private medical insurance. NDR holders do not access the public Medical Benefits Scheme.
benefits.pension: No access to the local pension system.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Relatively simple and handled entirely online. Requires standard documentation (proof of income, employment, insurance, clean criminal record). Processing time is typically 2-4 weeks.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Can be opened with the NDR visa approval. Requires standard KYC documents, and the process is moderately complex.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The government has streamlined the NDR process to be efficient. General day-to-day administration is typical of a small island nation.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official guidelines and expat reporting.

visas.bonuses_incentives: Extremely low cost of living in USD terms.
visas.remarks: üá¶üá∑ Extremely low cost of living due to currency situation. No official minimum income, but applicants must demonstrate sufficient funds (est. ~$2,500/month). The visa provides a temporary residence status and a DNI (national ID card). The application can be started online but often requires a consulate visit.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: A temporary residence permit for 'Digital Nomads' is available. It is granted for 180 days and can be renewed once for the same period.
legal_pathways.self_employment: The 'Rentista' visa is an option for those who can prove a stable passive income (e.g., from rent, dividends) sufficient to cover living costs.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: An investor visa is available for those who present a business plan to invest a significant amount in a productive, commercial, or service activity in Argentina.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Digital nomad visa holders are generally not considered tax residents, as their stay is limited to one year. If an individual stays longer and becomes a tax resident (typically after 12 months), they are subject to progressive tax rates up to 35% on their worldwide income.
tax_system.special_regimes: None specifically for digital nomads. The primary benefit is remaining a non-resident for tax purposes.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Non-residents are only taxed on Argentine-source income. As DNV holders work for foreign entities, their income is not considered Argentine-sourced.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable to DNV holders.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Foreigners on the digital nomad visa are not required to contribute to the Argentine social security system (ANSES).

benefits.healthcare: It is a mandatory requirement for the visa to have comprehensive health insurance. Argentina has a public healthcare system accessible to all, including tourists and temporary residents, but quality is variable, and private insurance is highly recommended.
benefits.pension: No access to the local pension system.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity. The application can be started online via the RaDEX system, but often requires a visit to an Argentine consulate abroad to finalize. It requires a significant number of documents, which must be apostilled and officially translated into Spanish.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Difficult. Opening a full-service bank account requires a CUIL/CUIT (tax ID number) and a DNI (national ID card), which you receive after your residency is approved. Dealing with the banking system and currency controls is a major challenge.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Bureaucracy is known to be slow, complex, and paper-intensive. Processes often require in-person visits, and the rules can seem opaque. Navigating the system without a local facilitator or fluent Spanish is very difficult.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official guidelines and expat reporting.

visas.bonuses_incentives: Easy short-term remote work, no income tax.
visas.remarks: üèùÔ∏è This is a program for tourists, not a formal visa. No application fee is required, but mandatory visitor insurance is. Only available to nationals who do not require a visa to enter Aruba for tourism. You cannot work for any Aruban individual or company.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The 'One Happy Workation' program allows visa-free nationals (like those from the US) to stay and work remotely for up to 90 days. It is not a formal visa but a long-stay tourism initiative.
legal_pathways.self_employment: Requires a formal business or director's permit and establishing a local company, a much more complex process than the Workation program.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: Residency can be obtained by purchasing real estate, although this does not automatically grant the right to work.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Participants in the One Happy Workation program are not subject to local Aruban income tax on their foreign-sourced income. For residents, a high progressive tax rate applies, which can go up to 52%.
tax_system.special_regimes: The tax exemption for foreign income is the key benefit for the Workation program.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Not applicable to Workation participants on their remote work income.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable to Workation participants. For residents, contributions to the General Health Insurance (AZV) and pension funds are mandatory.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Not applicable to Workation participants.

benefits.healthcare: Workation participants are required to purchase Aruba's mandatory COVID-19 visitor insurance and are advised to have their own comprehensive travel/health insurance. They do not access the local AZV system.
benefits.pension: No access to the local pension system.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Very simple. There is no visa application. You simply book travel and accommodations that are part of the program and meet the standard entry requirements for Aruba.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Very difficult for non-residents on a short-term stay. Not a practical option for Workation participants.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Minimal bureaucracy for the program itself. General administration in Aruba is influenced by the Dutch system and is generally efficient.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official program information.

visas.bonuses_incentives: English-speaking; no taxes on foreign income.
visas.remarks: üê† High income requirement ($75,000/year for individuals) but tax-free on foreign earnings. Family income requirement is $100,000 per year. The application is submitted via email.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The 'Work Where You Vacation' program allows a 6-month stay for remote workers, which is renewable. Requires an annual income of $75,000 (individual) or $100,000 (couple/family).
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the 'Work Where You Vacation' program.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: The 'Qualified Retired Persons (QRP)' program is a popular path for those over 40 with a passive monthly income of at least $2,000. It offers significant tax exemptions.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Belize operates on a territorial tax system. Participants in the 'Work Where You Vacation' program are exempt from income tax on earnings generated abroad.
tax_system.special_regimes: The tax exemption is the key benefit. For residents earning local income, a 25% tax rate applies to income above a certain threshold.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Not applicable to program participants on their foreign income.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable to program participants.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Program participants are not required to contribute to the Belize Social Security Board.

benefits.healthcare: It is a mandatory requirement for the visa to have comprehensive international health insurance with at least $50,000 in coverage. Program participants do not use the public healthcare system.
benefits.pension: No access to the local pension system.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity. The application and required documents (proof of income, bank reference, clean criminal record) are submitted via email. After approval, the visa fee is paid upon arrival in Belize. Processing can take several weeks.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Difficult for non-residents. Opening an account often requires a local reference and significant due diligence.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The visa process is clearly defined. General administration can be slow, and processes are not as digitized as in other countries. English as the official language is a major advantage.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official guidelines and expat reporting.

visas.bonuses_incentives: Path towards permanent residency.
visas.remarks: üáßüá∑ Low income requirement of $1,500/month or $18,000 in savings. Must apply in person at a Brazilian consulate. After arrival, must register with the Federal Police within 90 days to obtain the national migrant identity card (CRNM).

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The Temporary Visa XIV (VITEM XIV) is available for remote workers. It requires a minimum monthly income of $1,500 from a foreign source OR bank savings of at least $18,000.
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the VITEM XIV visa.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: An investor visa (VITEM IX) is available for individuals who invest at least R$500,000 in a Brazilian company or real estate.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: A foreigner becomes a tax resident if they hold a temporary visa and stay in Brazil for more than 183 days within a 12-month period. Residents are taxed on their worldwide income at progressive rates from 7.5% to 27.5%.
tax_system.special_regimes: No special tax regimes exist for digital nomads. Standard tax residency rules apply.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: For the first 183 days, you are a non-resident and only taxed on Brazilian-sourced income (which should be zero for a nomad).

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable to DNV holders.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Foreigners on a digital nomad visa are generally not required to contribute to the Brazilian social security system (INSS).

benefits.healthcare: It is a mandatory requirement for the visa to have valid health insurance covering the entire territory of Brazil. While Brazil has a public health system (SUS) that is free at the point of use for everyone (including tourists), it is often overburdened, and visa holders must have private coverage.
benefits.pension: No access to the local pension system.

bureaucracy.visa_process: High complexity. Requires submitting extensive, often apostilled, documents to a Brazilian consulate abroad. After receiving the visa and arriving in Brazil, it is mandatory to register with the Federal Police within 90 days. This registration process requires another set of documents and an in-person appointment to get the national migrant identity card (CRNM).
bureaucracy.bank_account: Difficult. Requires a CPF (taxpayer ID number) and a CRNM. Some fintechs may offer accounts with fewer requirements, but traditional banking is tied to residency status.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The system is known to be highly bureaucratic and slow. Getting the CPF, scheduling the Federal Police appointment, and navigating the system often requires patience and Portuguese language skills or local assistance.
bureaucracy.source: https://help.unhcr.org/brazil/en/solicitacao-da-condicao-de-refugiado/como-solicitar-a-minha-crnm/

visas.bonuses_incentives: No local income tax.
visas.remarks: ‚ùå This program is permanently closed to new applicants as of 2022. It had a very high income requirement and application fee. It was known for its 0% tax and luxury lifestyle.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The Global Citizen Concierge Program (GCCP) was launched in 2020 but is no longer accepting new applications until further notice.
legal_pathways.self_employment: This requires a standard work permit sponsored by a locally licensed company. It is not a path for independent freelancers working for foreign clients.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: Residency can be obtained through a minimum investment of US$1.2 million, with at least US$610,000 in developed real estate. This grants a 25-year renewable residency certificate.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: There is no personal income tax, capital gains tax, or inheritance tax in the Cayman Islands.
tax_system.special_regimes: The entire jurisdiction operates as a tax-neutral territory for personal and corporate income.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Not applicable.

contribution_rates.employed: For residents on a work permit, mandatory contributions to a private pension plan are required (typically 5% from employee, 5% from employer).
contribution_rates.self_employed: Not applicable for remote workers. Resident self-employed individuals must also contribute to a private pension.

benefits.healthcare: There is no public healthcare system. All residents are required by law to have private health insurance coverage from a locally approved provider. This is a significant monthly expense.
benefits.pension: A mandatory private pension system ensures retirement savings for residents.

bureaucracy.visa_process: With the GCCP closed, obtaining long-term residency is a very complex and expensive process, typically requiring legal assistance and substantial investment.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Very difficult for non-residents. Opening an account requires extensive due diligence, professional references, and a clear, substantial reason for needing a Caymanian account.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Bureaucracy is efficient and professional, following British standards, but is also very rigid and requires precise adherence to rules.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official guidelines and legal publications.

visas.bonuses_incentives: Low income requirement, easy online application.
visas.remarks: üá®üá¥ Very low income requirement (3x Colombia's minimum wage, approx. ~$900 USD). Straightforward online application process. After approval, must register the visa with Migraci√≥n Colombia and obtain a C√©dula de Extranjer√≠a (foreigner's ID card).

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The V-type Digital Nomad visa is available for remote workers from visa-exempt countries. It requires a minimum monthly income of 3x the Colombian minimum wage.
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the digital nomad visa for freelancers working with foreign clients.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: An M-type (Migrant) visa is available for those who invest a significant amount in real estate or a local company.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: If you stay in Colombia for more than 183 days in a 365-day period, you become a tax resident. Tax residents are subject to tax on their worldwide income at progressive rates from 0% to 39%.
tax_system.special_regimes: No special tax regimes exist for digital nomads. Standard tax residency rules apply.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: For the first 183 days, you are a non-resident and not taxed on foreign income.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable for DNV holders.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Foreigners on a V-type visitor visa (like the digital nomad visa) are not required to join the Colombian health or pension system (EPS).

benefits.healthcare: It is a mandatory requirement for the visa to have a private international health insurance policy with coverage in Colombia for the entire duration of the stay.
benefits.pension: No access to the local pension system.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity. The initial application is done online. After approval, you must register the visa with Migraci√≥n Colombia and then apply for your C√©dula de Extranjer√≠a (Foreigner ID card), which requires an in-person appointment. This entire post-arrival process must be completed within 15 days of entering the country.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Difficult without a C√©dula de Extranjer√≠a. Once you have the foreigner ID card, opening an account is straightforward.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The system can be slow and bureaucratic, especially when scheduling appointments with Migraci√≥n Colombia. Having all documents perfectly in order is crucial. The language barrier can be an issue in official settings.
bureaucracy.source: https://srislawyer.com/foreigners-id-card-cedula-de-extranjeria/

visas.bonuses_incentives: Full income tax exemption.
visas.remarks: pura vida! üå¥ This visa offers a full exemption from local income tax. The application is online, but can be slow (4-8 weeks). Family income requirement is $4,000/month. After approval, must get a DIMEX (residency) card in person.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The 'Estancia por Teletrabajo' is available for remote workers with a stable monthly income of at least $3,000 USD (or $4,000 for a family).
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the digital nomad visa for work with foreign clients.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: The 'Rentista' and 'Inversionista' visas are alternatives for those with passive income or who make a significant investment (e.g., $150,000) in the country.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Holders of the digital nomad visa are fully exempt from paying Costa Rican income tax on their foreign-sourced income.
tax_system.special_regimes: The tax exemption is the key benefit. Costa Rica operates a territorial tax system, so only income generated from within Costa Rica is taxed.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Not applicable to digital nomad visa holders on their foreign income.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable for DNV holders.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Digital nomad visa holders are not required to pay into the Costa Rican Social Security Fund (CCSS).

benefits.healthcare: It is a mandatory requirement for the visa to have a private international health insurance policy with a minimum coverage of $50,000 USD for the entire duration of the stay.
benefits.pension: No access to the local pension system.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity. The application is submitted online via the official portal. All foreign documents must be apostilled and officially translated into Spanish. After the application is approved, the applicant must schedule an in-person appointment in Costa Rica to be issued their Foreigner Identity Card (DIMEX).
bureaucracy.bank_account: Can be opened once you have your DIMEX card. Difficult to open without resident status.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The system is known to be bureaucratic and slow, but the digital nomad visa process is more streamlined than traditional residency paths. Still, patience is required for the final steps of getting the DIMEX card.
bureaucracy.source: https://quatro.legal/dimex-cards/

visas.bonuses_incentives: Fast processing, simple application.
visas.remarks: üá®üáº No specific income requirement, but you must sign a declaration of solvency. Quick and easy online application process, typically approved within 2 weeks. You remain a tax resident of your home country.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The '@Home in Cura√ßao' program is available for remote workers, offering a 6-month stay that can be renewed for another 6 months.
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the '@Home' program for freelancers. Establishing a local business requires a different, more complex 'investor permit'.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: A residence permit for investors is available, requiring a business investment of at least ANG 500,000 (~$280,000) or a real estate purchase of a similar value.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Participants in the '@Home' program are not considered tax residents and are therefore not subject to local income tax on their foreign earnings. For residents, progressive rates apply, reaching up to 46.5%.
tax_system.special_regimes: The tax exemption is the key feature for nomads. A special 'pensionado' regime exists for retirees, offering a low flat tax rate on foreign pension income.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Not applicable to '@Home' participants on their remote work income.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable to program participants.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Not applicable to program participants.

benefits.healthcare: It is mandatory for applicants to have valid international health insurance. They do not contribute to or benefit from the local social security system.
benefits.pension: No access to the local pension system.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Simple and efficient. The application is submitted entirely online with a typical processing time of two weeks.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Difficult for non-residents on a temporary program. Most participants rely on their home country banking services.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The program itself is streamlined. General administration on the island is influenced by the Dutch system and is relatively organized.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official program information.

visas.bonuses_incentives: Nature-focused lifestyle, income tax waiver.
visas.remarks: üçÉ Live and work in the 'Nature Isle' of the Caribbean. Requires an expected annual income of $50,000. High application fee ($100 application fee + $800 visa fee). Family bundle visa costs $1,200.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The 'Work in Nature' (WIN) visa allows remote workers to live and work in Dominica for up to 18 months. Requires an anticipated income of $50,000 USD.
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the WIN visa for freelancers.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: Dominica runs a well-known 'Citizenship by Investment' program, providing a passport for a minimum contribution of $100,000 to a government fund or a $200,000 real estate investment.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Holders of the WIN visa receive a waiver on income tax for their foreign-sourced earnings.
tax_system.special_regimes: The tax waiver is the key benefit. For residents, progressive income tax rates apply from 15% to 35%.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Not applicable to WIN visa holders on their remote work income.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable for WIN visa holders. For local employees, the employee contributes 7% and the employer 8.25% to the Dominica Social Security.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Not applicable for WIN visa holders.

benefits.healthcare: It is a mandatory requirement for the visa to have private health insurance. WIN visa holders do not access the public health system.
benefits.pension: No access to the local pension system.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity. The application is submitted online. Requires a clean criminal record from every country lived in for the past 5 years. Processing can take up to 28 days.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Difficult for non-residents on a temporary visa. Relying on international banking is standard.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The WIN program is well-defined. General day-to-day administration is typical for a small Caribbean nation and may be slower than in larger countries.
bureaucracy.source: https://www.immigrationua.com/dominica-digital-nomad-visa/

visas.visa_name: Digital Nomad Visa (Rentista for Remote Work)
visas.bonuses_incentives: Path toward permanent residency, uses the US dollar.
visas.remarks: üá™üá® Very low cost of living and uses the US dollar. Low income requirement (3x Ecuador's basic salary, which is $465 for 2025). The visa fee is $400 plus a $50 application fee. After approval, must get a Cedula (ID card).

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The 'Rentista for Remote Work' visa is available. It requires a minimum monthly income of 3x the unified basic salary (~$1,395 for 2025).
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the nomad visa. A 'Professional' (9-V) visa is also an option for those with a university degree from an approved list, but it has more complex requirements.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: An investor visa is available for those who invest at least $46,500 (100x the basic salary) in real estate or a certificate of deposit in an Ecuadorian bank.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Ecuador operates on a territorial tax system. This means that foreign-sourced income is not taxed in Ecuador, which is a major benefit for digital nomads. Only income generated from within Ecuador is subject to tax.
tax_system.special_regimes: The territorial tax system is the primary benefit.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Not applicable to the foreign income of digital nomads.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable for DNV holders.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Voluntary affiliation with the Ecuadorian Institute of Social Security (IESS) is possible but not mandatory for digital nomad visa holders. Those who join pay a percentage of a declared income base.

benefits.healthcare: It is a mandatory requirement for the visa to have a private international health insurance policy. Those who voluntarily affiliate with IESS can access the public health system.
benefits.pension: Access is available only to those who voluntarily contribute to IESS.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate to high complexity. The application can be submitted online or at an Ecuadorian consulate. All foreign documents (e.g., apostilled criminal record) must be translated into Spanish. After visa approval, it is mandatory to apply for a 'Cedula' (national ID card) in person in Ecuador.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Can be opened once you have your temporary residency and Cedula. Very difficult without them.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The system is known to be bureaucratic and can be slow. A good understanding of Spanish or the help of a local facilitator is highly recommended for navigating the visa and Cedula processes.
bureaucracy.source: https://thenomadalmanac.com/ecuador-digital-nomad-visa/

visas.bonuses_incentives: No income, capital gains, or property tax on foreign assets.
visas.remarks: ‚Çø The first country to make Bitcoin legal tender. The Digital Nomad Visa offers significant tax advantages. The income requirement is 4x the local minimum wage. The application can be started online, but may require a consulate visit to finalize.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: A Digital Nomad Visa is available, granting a one-year temporary residency, renewable up to four years. It requires a monthly income of at least $1,460 USD.
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the Digital Nomad Visa for freelancers working with foreign clients.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: The 'Freedom Visa Program' offers citizenship for a $1 million donation in Bitcoin or USDT, limited to 1,000 applicants per year.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: El Salvador operates a territorial tax system. Digital Nomad Visa holders are not taxed on their foreign-sourced income.
tax_system.special_regimes: The tax exemption on foreign income is the key benefit. Additionally, there is no capital gains tax on Bitcoin and no property tax.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Not applicable to the foreign income of digital nomads.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable for DNV holders.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Digital Nomad Visa holders are not required to contribute to the Salvadoran Social Security Institute (ISSS).

benefits.healthcare: It is a mandatory requirement for the visa to have a private international health insurance policy. Visa holders do not access the public health system.
benefits.pension: No access to the local pension system.

social_security.source: Claude, based on standard DNV requirements.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity. The application can be initiated online, but requires submitting apostilled and translated documents to a Salvadoran consulate. Processing is estimated at around 45 days.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Difficult for non-residents. Opening an account typically requires a local residency card (NIT). The prevalence of Bitcoin and digital wallets provides an alternative.
bureaucracy.general_admin: As a newer program, processes are still being established. General administration can be slow, and Spanish is essential for navigating government offices.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of available program information.

visas.bonuses_incentives: Tax exemptions and beautiful environment.
visas.remarks: üá¨üá© Live on the 'Island of Spice'. Requires an annual income of EC$100,000 (approx. $37,000 USD, though most sources state $50,000). High application fee: $1,500 for individuals, $2,000 for families. You are exempt from paying local income tax.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The Remote Employment Act of 2021 provides a visa for remote workers. It requires an annual income of at least $50,000 USD.
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the remote employment visa for freelancers with foreign clients.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: A well-established Citizenship by Investment program offers a passport for a minimum contribution of $150,000 to the National Transformation Fund or a $220,000 real estate investment.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Holders of the remote employment visa are exempt from paying Grenadian income tax on their foreign-sourced income.
tax_system.special_regimes: The tax exemption is the key benefit. For other residents, progressive income tax rates up to 30% apply.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Not applicable to visa holders on their remote work income.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable for remote employment visa holders. The law states that every employee/self-employed person in Grenada must contribute to the National Insurance Scheme (NIS).
contribution_rates.self_employed: While the law is broad, in practice, temporary remote workers for foreign entities are generally not enrolled in the NIS system.

benefits.healthcare: It is a mandatory requirement for the visa to have a private international health insurance policy.
benefits.pension: No access to the local pension system.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity. The application and documents are submitted by mail to the Grenadian embassy. Processing takes approximately 10 business days after receipt.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Difficult for non-residents on a temporary visa. Relying on international banking is standard.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The visa process is well-defined. General administration is typical for a small Caribbean nation. English as the official language is a major advantage.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official guidelines and visa agency information.

visas.visa_name: Bahamas Extended Access Travel Stay (BEATS) Program
visas.bonuses_incentives: 0% income tax environment. Pathway to PR via investment.

cost_of_living.accommodation: ~$1,000-3,000/month for a one-bedroom apartment in Nassau.
cost_of_living.transportation: Public transport is affordable (~$1.50/trip), but owning a car is very expensive.
cost_of_living.overall_index: Very High. Ranks among the world's most expensive locations.

visas.remarks: üáßüá∏ Streamlined online application with a 5-day processing target. The permit fee is $1,000 for the primary applicant and $500 for each dependent. The final permit is delivered digitally with a QR code.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The BEATS Program is the primary pathway for remote workers.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: Economic Permanent Residency is available via a minimum real estate investment of $1 million USD.
legal_pathways.other: An Annual Residence Permit ($1,000/year) and a Home Owner's Card ($250/year) are also available for shorter-term stays. Citizenship requires 10 years of PR and renunciation of previous nationality.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: 0% personal income tax, capital gains tax, and dividend tax.
tax_system.vat: A standard Value Added Tax (VAT) of 10% applies to most goods and services.
tax_system.other_taxes: Very high customs duties on imported goods (e.g., 35% on electronics, 45% on cars) significantly increase living costs. Property tax is also a key revenue source.

contribution_rates.employed: 11.3% of wages for local employees (split between employee/employer).
contribution_rates.self_employed: 10.3% for locally self-employed persons.

benefits.healthcare: BEATS participants are not entitled to public benefits and must have comprehensive private health insurance.
benefits.pension: No entitlement for BEATS participants.

social_security.applicability_to_nomads: It is inferred that BEATS participants are exempt from National Insurance Board (NIB) contributions, as the program is designed for foreign-employed individuals and mandatory contributions would be administratively complex.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Low. The BEATS application is fully online, streamlined, and fast.
bureaucracy.bank_account: High. Opening an account is subject to rigorous AML/KYC checks, requiring extensive documentation on the source of funds. The sector is geared more toward private wealth management than retail banking for temporary residents.
bureaucracy.general_admin: A mix of efficient, modern systems for attracting investment and tourism, contrasted with more traditional bureaucracy in other areas.
bureaucracy.source: https://cbb.bs/

visas.bonuses_incentives: Legally codified 0% income tax and social security exemption for visa holders.

cost_of_living.accommodation: ~$540-700/month for a one-bedroom apartment in Bridgetown.
cost_of_living.food: Groceries are expensive due to reliance on imports.
cost_of_living.transportation: Public transport is affordable; car ownership is expensive.
cost_of_living.overall_index: Moderate to High. More affordable than Bermuda or The Bahamas.

visas.remarks: üáßüáß The application process is fully online and very efficient, with a 5-7 working day turnaround. A key advantage is the Remote Employment Act, 2020, which provides legal certainty on the tax and social security exemptions.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The Barbados Welcome Stamp is a purpose-built program for remote workers.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: The Special Entry and Residence Permit (SERP) offers immediate permanent residency for a $2M investment, or a 5-year renewable permit for a $300,000 real estate investment.
legal_pathways.other: A pathway to citizenship is available after 7 years of continuous residence.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Welcome Stamp holders are explicitly deemed non-resident for tax purposes by the Remote Employment Act, 2020, and pay 0% income tax on foreign-sourced income.
tax_system.vat: Subject to standard Value Added Tax (VAT) on local goods and services.

contribution_rates.employed: 23.75% for local employees (split between employee/employer).

benefits.healthcare: Welcome Stamp holders are not entitled to local benefits and must have private health insurance.

social_security.applicability_to_nomads: An explicit and legally codified exemption exists. Welcome Stamp holders are not required to make contributions to the National Insurance Scheme (NIS).

bureaucracy.visa_process: Very Low. The Welcome Stamp application is consistently cited as one of the simplest, fastest, and most user-friendly digital processes available.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Low to Moderate. Several banks cater to foreign clients, and it is possible to open an account 100% remotely before arrival with standard KYC documentation.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Generally considered low-bureaucracy, with family-friendly processes that allow for easy enrollment of children in local schools.
bureaucracy.source: https://www.barbadoswelcomestamp.bb/

visas.visa_name: Permission to Reside on an Annual Basis
visas.bonuses_incentives: 0% income tax environment in a high-quality location.

cost_of_living.accommodation: Astronomical. ~$3,434/month for a one-bedroom apartment in Hamilton.
cost_of_living.food: Extremely high. A gallon of milk can cost over $16 USD.
cost_of_living.overall_index: Extremely High. Consistently ranked as one of the most expensive places in the world.

visas.remarks: üáßüá≤ This is a general residency permit, not a dedicated nomad visa. It replaced the 'Work from Bermuda Certificate' which ended Feb 28, 2025. The application process is slow (approx. 12 weeks). Significant ambiguity exists regarding payroll tax liability for remote workers.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The 'Permission to Reside on an Annual Basis' is the current pathway for remote workers.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: The Economic Investment Residential Certificate (EIRC) grants indefinite residency for a $2.5 million investment in approved assets.
legal_pathways.other: A path to British Overseas Territories Citizenship (Bermuda) is possible after 10 years of residency.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: 0% personal income tax, capital gains, and withholding tax.
tax_system.other_taxes: A complex Payroll Tax exists. Its applicability to remote workers is a significant legal gray area, creating a compliance risk. A formal ruling from the Tax Commissioner is advised.

contribution_rates.employed: A flat weekly rate of $71.84 BMD, split 50/50 between employee and employer.

benefits.healthcare: After contributions are made, residents gain access to the Contributory Pension Fund and associated benefits.
benefits.pension: Contributory state pension system.

social_security.applicability_to_nomads: Mandatory. A '26-week trap' exists where non-residents working in Bermuda for more than 26 consecutive weeks become liable for social insurance contributions for the entire period, amounting to ~$3,735 annually.

bureaucracy.visa_process: High. The 12-week processing time indicates a much more rigorous and document-intensive process than other Caribbean nomad visas.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Very High. The process is notoriously difficult for non-residents, with banks catering to corporations and high-net-worth clients, often requiring very high minimum deposits (e.g., $250,000 USD).
bureaucracy.general_admin: Considered more rigorous and challenging than neighboring island jurisdictions.
bureaucracy.source: https://www.gov.bm/department/immigration

visas.bonuses_incentives: 0% direct tax jurisdiction. Fast track to PR via a competitive investment program.

cost_of_living.transportation: Car rental or ownership is common; public transport is limited.
cost_of_living.overall_index: High. An expensive destination due to reliance on imports.

visas.remarks: üá¶üáÆ Officially named the 'Work from Anguilla' program. The fee is $2,000 for an individual or $3,000 for a family of four. No official income minimum, but self-sufficiency must be demonstrated. Visa is non-renewable; a new application is required to extend stay.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The 'Work from Anguilla' Digital Nomad Visa is the main remote work pathway.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: A competitive Residency by Investment program offers immediate PR for a $150,000 donation to the Capital Development Fund or a $400,000 real estate investment.
legal_pathways.other: Citizenship is available after 5 years of residency, and dual citizenship is permitted.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: 0% personal income tax, capital gains tax, inheritance tax, and corporate income tax on foreign-sourced earnings.
tax_system.other_taxes: Government revenue is primarily from customs duties on imported goods.

contribution_rates.employed: 10.5% of wages for the local workforce, split 50/50 between employee and employer.

benefits.healthcare: Digital nomad visa holders are not entitled to local benefits and must have private health insurance.

social_security.applicability_to_nomads: It is inferred that digital nomads and their foreign employers are exempt from contributing to the Anguilla Social Security Board (ASSB), as the system is based on local employment contracts.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Low. The online visa application is described as simple and efficient, with a processing time of 7-14 business days.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Moderate. Feasible for non-residents but requires standard international due diligence (ID, proof of address, source of funds). Local banks have established procedures for non-resident applicants.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Generally straightforward for processes related to the remote work program.
bureaucracy.source: https://evisa.gov.ai/

visas.bonuses_incentives: Proximity to North America, path to permanent residency.
visas.remarks: üåÆ Not a nomad visa, but a popular temporary residency path. Mexico's Temporary Resident Visa allows you to stay for 12 to 48 months, starting with an initial 1-year card that can be renewed up to 3 additional times. Must apply in person at a Mexican consulate outside of Mexico. Income requirements vary significantly by consulate (from ~$3,300 to ~$4,400/month). After approval, you must complete the 'canje' process in Mexico within 30 days to get your residence card.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: Mexico does not have a specific digital nomad visa. The 'Temporary Resident Visa' is the de facto option used by remote workers, obtained by proving economic solvency.
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the Temporary Resident Visa, as long as income is sourced from abroad.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: Residency can be obtained by purchasing property with a value exceeding a certain threshold (approx. $550,000 USD) or investing in a Mexican company.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: If you stay in Mexico for more than 183 days in a calendar year, you are generally considered a tax resident and are liable for tax on your worldwide income. Progressive rates range from 1.92% to 35%.
tax_system.special_regimes: No special regimes exist for remote workers. However, due to tax treaties, if you can prove you pay taxes elsewhere, you may avoid double taxation. This is a complex area requiring professional advice.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: For the first 183 days, you are a non-resident and not taxed on foreign income. Many nomads on this visa operate in a grey area regarding tax obligations.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable for remote workers.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Temporary residents are not required to contribute to the Mexican Social Security Institute (IMSS), but can voluntarily enroll to gain access to the public healthcare system.

benefits.healthcare: Many expats and remote workers rely on private health insurance. Voluntary enrollment in the IMSS provides access to the public system, but it can be overburdened.
benefits.pension: No access to the local pension system unless contributing.

bureaucracy.visa_process: High complexity. It's a two-part process. First, an in-person interview at a Mexican consulate abroad to get the visa sticker. Second, upon arrival in Mexico, you have 30 days to begin the 'canje' process at a local INM immigration office to exchange the sticker for a temporary resident card. This second step is notoriously slow and bureaucratic.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Can be opened once you have your temporary resident card and a CURP (ID number). Difficult without them.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The system is known to be slow, paper-based, and difficult to navigate without fluent Spanish. INM appointments are hard to get, and processes can take months. Using an immigration lawyer or facilitator is very common.
bureaucracy.source: https://www.mexperience.com/rights-obligations-when-you-have-legal-residency-in-mexico/

visas.bonuses_incentives: Peaceful environment, tax exemptions.
visas.remarks: üåã Live on a quiet Caribbean island with an active volcano. High income requirement of $70,000/year. Application fee is $500 for individuals, $750 for families. Visa holders are not liable for local income tax.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The 'Montserrat Remote Work Stamp' is available for remote workers who can prove an annual income of at least $70,000 USD.
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the Remote Work Stamp for freelancers with foreign clients.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: Montserrat does not have a formal Citizenship by Investment program. Residency is tied to obtaining work or residence permits through standard immigration channels.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Holders of the Remote Work Stamp are not liable to pay Montserrat Income Tax on their foreign-sourced income.
tax_system.special_regimes: The tax exemption is the key benefit. For other residents, a progressive income tax system applies with rates from 5% to 40%.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Not applicable to Stamp holders on their remote work income.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable for Stamp holders. For local employees, the employee contributes 5.5% and the employer 6.5% to the Montserrat Social Security Fund.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Stamp holders are not required to contribute.

benefits.healthcare: It is a mandatory requirement for the visa to have a valid international health insurance policy. Stamp holders do not access the public health system.
benefits.pension: No access to the local pension system.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Simple and efficient. The application is submitted online and is typically processed within 7 working days.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Difficult for non-residents on a temporary stamp. Relying on international banking is standard.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The stamp program is streamlined. General administration on the island is typical for a small British Overseas Territory. English as the official language is a major advantage.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official guidelines.

visas.visa_length: 9 months, extendable once for another 9 months
visas.bonuses_incentives: No taxes on foreign income; U.S. dollar economy.
visas.remarks: ‚öñÔ∏è You must hire a Panamanian immigration lawyer to handle the application. 0% tax on foreign-sourced income. The official economy uses the U.S. Dollar. The application process must be done in person in Panama.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The 'Short-Stay Visa for Remote Workers' allows a 9-month stay, renewable once. It requires an annual income of at least $36,000 USD from a foreign source.
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the remote worker visa. An alternative is the 'Friendly Nations Visa' for citizens of 50 eligible countries, which offers a path to permanent residency but requires either a local job offer or a real estate investment of $200,000.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: A Qualified Investor visa offers expedited permanent residency for a minimum investment of $300,000 in real estate.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Panama operates a territorial tax system. Remote workers on the short-stay visa are not taxed on their foreign-sourced income.
tax_system.special_regimes: The territorial tax system is the key benefit.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Not applicable to visa holders on their remote work income.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable for remote worker visa holders. For local employees, the employee pays 9.75% and the employer 12.25%.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Remote worker visa holders are not required to contribute to Panama's social security fund.

benefits.healthcare: It is a mandatory requirement for the visa to have private health insurance with coverage in Panama. Visa holders do not access the public health system.
benefits.pension: No access to the local pension system.

bureaucracy.visa_process: High complexity because it is mandatory to hire a Panamanian immigration lawyer to submit the application in person at the immigration office in Panama. This increases the cost and administrative overhead. The processing time after submission is around 30-40 business days.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Relatively straightforward to open with a passport, a second ID, and a reference letter. Having a local lawyer can facilitate this process.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The reliance on lawyers for immigration processes is a key feature of the bureaucracy. Outside of this, general administration is typical for the region.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of law firm guidelines.

visas.bonuses_incentives: Retain foreign tax residency, low income requirement.
visas.remarks: üáµüá™ Recently launched! The visa is a sub-category of the 'Rentista' (person of independent means) visa. Low income requirement of $1,000/month makes it very accessible. Allows you to work remotely without becoming a Peruvian tax resident.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: A Digital Nomad visa is available as a sub-category under the 'Rentista' temporary residence. It requires a minimum monthly income of $1,000 from foreign sources.
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the digital nomad visa.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: An investor visa is available for those who invest at least PEN 500,000 (approx. $135,000) in a Peruvian company.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Digital nomad visa holders are not considered tax residents for their foreign income. For other residents (staying >183 days), a progressive tax system applies with rates from 8% to 30%.
tax_system.special_regimes: The key benefit is the exemption from Peruvian tax on foreign-sourced income for digital nomad visa holders.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Not applicable to the foreign income of digital nomads.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable for DNV holders. For local employees, the employee contributes ~13% to a pension fund, and the employer contributes 9% to health insurance.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Digital nomad visa holders are not required to contribute to the Peruvian social security system.

benefits.healthcare: It is a mandatory requirement for the visa to have a private international health insurance policy. Visa holders do not access the public EsSalud health system.
benefits.pension: No access to the local pension system (AFP/ONP).

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity. The application is submitted online via the 'Agencia Virtual' of the Peruvian immigration authority (Migraciones). All foreign documents must be apostilled and translated. After approval, an in-person appointment is required to obtain the 'Carn√© de Extranjer√≠a' (foreigner's ID card). Processing can take 1-3 months.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Can be opened once you have your Carn√© de Extranjer√≠a. Very difficult without it.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The system can be slow and requires patience. Navigating the Migraciones website and scheduling appointments can be challenging. A good understanding of Spanish is essential.
bureaucracy.source: https://www.wandrly.app/visas/peru

visas.eligible_citizens: US citizens or those with US work authorization.
visas.bonuses_incentives: Tax incentives under Act 60 for residents.
visas.remarks: üá∫üá∏ Not a visa, but a US territory. No visa needed for US citizens. Foreigners follow standard US entry rules (e.g., ESTA for tourism, but this does not permit work). The main draw for remote entrepreneurs is relocating to become a 'bona fide' resident and qualifying for major tax incentives under Act 60.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: No visa exists. US citizens can live and work freely. Non-US citizens must qualify for a standard US work visa (e.g., H-1B, O-1), which is unrelated to remote work.
legal_pathways.self_employment: The primary 'program' is achieving 'bona fide resident' status to qualify for Act 60 tax incentives. This requires passing several IRS tests, including being present in Puerto Rico for at least 183 days a year.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: Act 60's 'Individual Resident Investor' component offers 0% tax on capital gains for new residents. The 'Export Services' component offers a 4% corporate tax rate for businesses that export services from Puerto Rico.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: For bona fide residents under Act 60, Puerto Rico-sourced income is taxed at a very low rate (e.g., 4% for export service corporations) and all capital gains can be 0%. Residents not under Act 60 are subject to Puerto Rico's own progressive income tax system.
tax_system.special_regimes: Act 60 provides some of the most powerful tax incentives available to US citizens, including a 4% corporate tax rate and 0% tax on dividends and capital gains for qualifying individuals and businesses.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Standard US tax law applies.

contribution_rates.employed: Residents of Puerto Rico pay into the US Social Security and Medicare systems. Employees pay 6.2% for Social Security (on income up to the annual limit) and 1.45% for Medicare.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Self-employed individuals pay the full Self-Employment Tax, which is 12.4% for Social Security and 2.9% for Medicare.

benefits.healthcare: Puerto Rico is covered by the US Medicare system for eligible individuals. Many residents also have private health insurance.
benefits.pension: Residents contribute to and are eligible for US Social Security benefits.
benefits.unemployment: Puerto Rico has its own unemployment insurance program administered locally.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Not applicable for US citizens. The main process is applying for an Act 60 decree with the Puerto Rico Department of Economic Development and Commerce (DDEC), which requires significant legal and financial documentation.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Straightforward for US citizens, similar to opening an account in any US state.
bureaucracy.general_admin: A mix of US federal efficiency and local Caribbean bureaucracy. While systems are modern, processes can sometimes be slow. Establishing 'bona fide' residency requires careful record-keeping to meet IRS tests.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official guidelines for Act 60.

visas.bonuses_incentives: Easy application process, tropical lifestyle.
visas.remarks: üá±üá® This is a multiple-entry visa designed for remote work. No specific income requirement, but must prove you can support yourself. Low application fee makes it an attractive option. The application process is straightforward and handled online.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The 'Live It' program provides a multiple-entry visa for up to one year for remote workers. There is no specific income threshold, but applicants must demonstrate financial self-sufficiency.
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the 'Live It' program.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: Saint Lucia has a popular 'Citizenship by Investment' program, offering a passport for a minimum contribution of $100,000 to the National Economic Fund.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: If an individual stays in Saint Lucia for more than 183 days, they are considered a tax resident. Residents are taxed on worldwide income at progressive rates of 15% and 30%.
tax_system.special_regimes: There are no special tax regimes for remote workers under the 'Live It' program; standard residency rules apply.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Non-residents are taxed only on income sourced from Saint Lucia.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable for 'Live It' participants.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Remote workers on the 'Live It' visa are not required to contribute to the National Insurance Corporation (NIC).

benefits.healthcare: It is recommended to have private international health insurance. The public healthcare system is available, but most expats prefer private facilities.
benefits.pension: No access to the local pension system.

social_security.source: Claude, based on standard DNV program structures.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Simple and efficient. The application is handled online with a relatively quick turnaround time.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Difficult for non-residents on a temporary program. Relying on international banking is standard.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The 'Live It' program is streamlined. General administration on the island is typical for a small Caribbean nation. English as the official language is a major advantage.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official program information.

visas.visa_length: 6 months, renewable once for another 6 months
visas.bonuses_incentives: Path to permanent residency, strong digital infrastructure.
visas.remarks: üá∫üáæ Unique for its lack of a specific income requirement. You only need to sign a sworn affidavit promising self-sufficiency. After the initial permit, you can apply for a 2-year temporary residency, which is a path to permanent residency and citizenship.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: A permit for remote workers is available, granting a 6-month stay, renewable once. It does not have a minimum income requirement but requires a sworn affidavit of sufficient funds.
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the digital nomad permit.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: Residency can be obtained by investing over $540,000 USD in real estate or over $2.3 million in a business that creates jobs. The 'Rentista' visa requires a passive income of at least $1,500/month.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Uruguay has a 'tax holiday' for new residents. You can choose a 10-year exemption on foreign-sourced interest and dividends, or pay a permanent flat rate of 7% on them. Income from remote work for foreign clients is generally considered foreign-sourced and therefore not taxed under this system. After the holiday, the standard rate on foreign dividends/interest is 12%.
tax_system.special_regimes: The tax holiday is the key benefit for new residents.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Not applicable to the foreign income of digital nomads.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable for DNV holders.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Foreigners on the digital nomad permit are not required to contribute to the social security system (BPS).

benefits.healthcare: It is a mandatory requirement for the permit to have comprehensive local health insurance. Uruguay has a high-quality, affordable private healthcare system known as 'mutualistas'.
benefits.pension: No access to the local pension system.

social_security.source: Claude, based on standard DNV program structures.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Simple initial application. The process is done online after entering Uruguay as a tourist. It requires creating a digital ID and submitting documents. After approval, you must get a 'C√©dula de Identidad' (ID card), which is a separate process.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Can be opened once you have your C√©dula. Difficult without it.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Uruguay is known for having a modern and relatively efficient bureaucracy, especially for a Latin American country. Many processes are digitized. Spanish is essential for navigating the system.
bureaucracy.source: https://nomadgirl.co/uruguay-digital-nomad-visa/

visas.visa_length: 12 months, with renewal options up to 3 years
visas.eligible_citizens: Citizens of eligible partner countries, aged 18-30 or 18-35.
visas.bonuses_incentives: Allows for incidental work while travelling.

cost_of_living.overall_index: Very high, among world's most expensive

visas.remarks: üá¶üá∫ This is a youth travel visa, not a nomad visa. Remote work is tolerated but the primary purpose must be tourism. Strict age (18-35) and nationality requirements apply. Requires proof of sufficient funds (~AUD 5,000) and a return ticket.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: Australia does not offer a specific digital nomad visa. The most common alternative is the Working Holiday Maker program (visas 417 and 462) for eligible young people.
legal_pathways.self_employment: Requires a much more complex visa, such as the Business Innovation and Investment visa, and is not suitable for freelancers working for foreign clients.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: Several streams exist under the Business Innovation and Investment program, requiring significant capital investment (e.g., AUD 2.5 million).
