tax_system.personal_income_tax: Tax residency is complex and determined by several factors, not just a 183-day rule. If deemed a tax resident, you are taxed on worldwide income at progressive rates from 16% to 45% (plus a 2% Medicare levy). Working Holiday Makers are taxed at 15% on income up to $45,000.
tax_system.special_regimes: No special regimes exist for remote workers. The tax system is complex.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: If deemed a foreign resident for tax purposes, you are taxed only on Australian-sourced income, typically at higher rates starting at 30%.

contribution_rates.employed: If working for an Australian employer, the employer must contribute an additional 11% of your salary to a superannuation (pension) fund. This is mandatory for almost all employees, including those on Working Holiday visas.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Not applicable for most remote workers on temporary visas.

benefits.healthcare: Australia has a public health system (Medicare), but it is generally only available to citizens, permanent residents, and citizens of countries with a Reciprocal Health Care Agreement. All temporary visa holders are required to have adequate private health insurance.
benefits.pension: Temporary residents can claim their accumulated superannuation back (minus taxes) after they leave Australia permanently, through a process called the Departing Australia Superannuation Payment (DASP).
benefits.unemployment: No access to unemployment benefits for temporary residents.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity. Applications are done online via an ImmiAccount. Processing times can vary significantly, from a few days to several months, depending on the visa type and applicant's country.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Relatively easy to open. Most major Australian banks allow you to open an account online before you arrive, which you then activate in person with your passport and visa details.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The system is highly digitized and efficient but very rule-based. Getting a Tax File Number (TFN) is a crucial first step for any work and is a straightforward online process.
bureaucracy.source: https://www.hrblock.com.au/tax-academy/what-is-a-tax-file-tfn

visas.visa_length: 6 months, renewable once for another 6 months
visas.eligible_citizens: Citizens of North America, Europe, CPLP, and ECOWAS
visas.bonuses_incentives: No local income tax on foreign earnings.
visas.remarks: üá®üáª Island life with a low cost of living. Requires a minimum bank balance of ‚Ç¨1,500 for the last 6 months. Visa fee (‚Ç¨20) and airport fee (‚Ç¨34) are paid on arrival. Application is online and processing is fast (approx. 2 weeks).

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The 'Remote Working Program' is available for citizens from Europe, North America, and Portuguese/West African speaking communities (CPLP, ECOWAS). It requires a minimum average bank balance of ‚Ç¨1,500 for individuals over the last six months.
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the Remote Working Program.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: Residency can be obtained through property investment or other capital transfers, but this is a separate and more complex process.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Participants in the Remote Working Program are exempt from local income tax on their foreign-sourced earnings.
tax_system.special_regimes: The tax exemption is the key benefit. For residents, a progressive tax system applies with rates from 16.5% to 27.5%.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Not applicable to program participants on their remote work income.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable for program participants. For local employment, the employee contributes 8.5% and the employer 16%.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Program participants are not required to contribute to the local social security system.

benefits.healthcare: It is a mandatory requirement for the visa to have valid international health insurance. Participants do not access the public health system.
benefits.pension: No access to the local pension system.

social_security.source: Claude, based on standard DNV program structures.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Simple and efficient online application. Processing is typically around two weeks. After approval, the fees are paid and the visa is stamped upon arrival in Cabo Verde.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Difficult for non-residents on a temporary program. Most participants rely on their home country banking services.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The visa program is streamlined. General administration on the islands can be slow. Portuguese is the official language, which can be a barrier.
bureaucracy.source: https://www.bi.cv/en/private/financial-solutions/3-deposito-a-ordem

visas.bonuses_incentives: Long-term stay option.
visas.remarks: üè∫ Not a work visa, but a long-term tourist visa that allows multiple entries over 5 years, with each stay limited to 90 days. This facilitates long-term presence through 'visa runs'. Remote work is tolerated but not officially sanctioned. High up-front cost.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: Egypt does not offer a specific digital nomad visa. The most relevant option is the new 5-year multiple-entry tourist visa, which allows for repeated long stays.
legal_pathways.self_employment: Requires establishing a local company and obtaining a work permit and residence visa, a very complex and bureaucratic process.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: A Citizenship by Investment program exists, requiring a minimum real estate purchase of $300,000 or a non-refundable contribution of $250,000.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: An individual becomes a tax resident if their main residence is in Egypt or if they are present for more than 183 days in a year. Residents are taxed on worldwide income. A new top bracket of 27.5% was recently added for high earners.
tax_system.special_regimes: No special regimes exist for remote workers.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Non-residents are only taxed on income earned from sources within Egypt.

contribution_rates.employed: For local employment, the employee contributes 11% and the employer 18.75%. Foreigners working in Egypt under a work permit are generally subject to these contributions.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Does not apply to those on a tourist visa.

benefits.healthcare: A public health system exists but is often under-resourced. Private healthcare and insurance are strongly recommended for expats.
benefits.pension: The social security system includes a pension scheme for contributing employees.

bureaucracy.visa_process: The 5-year visa application is handled by Egyptian consulates abroad and is a paper-based process. Extending a standard tourist visa from within Egypt at the 'Mugamma' (administrative building) is a notoriously bureaucratic and time-consuming experience.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Very difficult to open on a tourist visa. Requires proof of residency.
bureaucracy.general_admin: Considered highly bureaucratic. Processes are slow, require multiple physical documents and in-person visits, and can be unpredictable. The language barrier is significant in official settings.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official guidelines and extensive expat reporting.

visas.bonuses_incentives: No local income tax on foreign earnings.
visas.remarks: üá≤üá∫ This visa is completely free to apply for! Low income requirement ($1,500/month for individual). Dependents require an extra $500/month each in income. Tax-exempt on foreign-sourced income.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The 'Premium Travel Visa' is available for remote workers. It requires a monthly income of at least $1,500 USD (or equivalent) from foreign sources.
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the Premium Visa. Alternatively, one can apply for a Self-Employed Occupation Permit, but this requires an initial investment and is intended for those serving the local market.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: Residency can be obtained through the purchase of property in a designated scheme (e.g., PDS) for a minimum of $375,000 USD.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Holders of the Premium Visa are not considered tax residents and are therefore not subject to Mauritian tax on their foreign-sourced income. For tax residents (staying >183 days), a progressive tax system with rates up to 20% applies to worldwide income.
tax_system.special_regimes: The tax exemption is the key benefit of the Premium Visa.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Not applicable to Premium Visa holders on their remote work income.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable for Premium Visa holders. For local employment, both employee and employer contribute to the National Pension Fund (NPF).
contribution_rates.self_employed: Premium Visa holders are not required to contribute to Mauritian social security.

benefits.healthcare: It is a mandatory requirement for the visa to have a valid international health insurance policy. While Mauritius has a free public healthcare system, most expats use private clinics.
benefits.pension: No access to the local pension system.

social_security.source: Claude, based on standard DNV program structures.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Simple and efficient. The application is submitted online via the Economic Development Board (EDB) portal. It is free of charge and typically processed within 48 hours.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Can be opened with a passport and proof of address. The Premium Visa can help facilitate the process.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The visa program is very streamlined. General administration is a mix of French and British systems and is generally manageable. English and French are widely spoken.
bureaucracy.source: https://nomadgirl.co/mauritius-digital-nomad-visa-premium-visa/

visas.bonuses_incentives: No local income tax on foreign earnings for stays under 183 days.
visas.remarks: üá≤üá¶ Common unofficial nomad base. Most nationalities can enter visa-free for 90 days. For longer stays, it is sometimes possible to get an extension, but this process is difficult and unpredictable. A formal digital nomad visa has been announced but is not yet implemented.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: Morocco does not have a specific digital nomad visa. The common practice is to use the 90-day visa-free entry for tourism.
legal_pathways.self_employment: Requires establishing a local company and applying for a residence permit ('Carte de S√©jour'), a complex and slow process.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: No formal investment visa exists, but residency can be obtained through business formation.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: If an individual stays in Morocco for more than 183 days in a 365-day period, they become a tax resident and are subject to tax on their worldwide income at progressive rates up to 38%.
tax_system.special_regimes: No special regimes exist for remote workers.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: For the first 183 days, you are a non-resident and not taxed on foreign income.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable for remote workers on a tourist stay. For local employees, contributions to the CNSS are mandatory for both employee and employer.
contribution_rates.self_employed: A new regime requires resident self-employed individuals to contribute to the CNSS.

benefits.healthcare: The public healthcare system is available but often strained. Private healthcare and insurance are recommended for expats.
benefits.pension: The CNSS includes a pension scheme for contributors.

bureaucracy.visa_process: The 90-day tourist entry is simple. However, obtaining a residence permit ('Carte de S√©jour') for a longer stay is a very bureaucratic process, requiring extensive documentation, police checks, and multiple visits to different government offices.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Difficult to open on a tourist entry. Requires proof of residency ('Carte de S√©jour').
bureaucracy.general_admin: Bureaucracy is known to be slow, paper-based, and can be frustrating. The language barrier (French and Arabic are official) is a significant factor in all official dealings.
bureaucracy.source: https://www.theglobetrottingaccountant.com/morocco-digital-nomad-visa/

visas.bonuses_incentives: Tax exemptions and unique landscapes.
visas.remarks: üá≥üá¶ Explore stunning desert landscapes while you work. Income requirements increase by $1,000/month for a spouse and $500/month per child. The application is submitted online, and the visa is issued upon arrival.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The Namibia Digital Nomad Visa is available for remote workers. It requires a monthly income of at least $2,000 for an individual, $3,000 for a couple, and an additional $500 per child.
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the Digital Nomad Visa for freelancers.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: A residence permit can be obtained through a significant business investment, but this is a more complex process.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Namibia has a source-based tax system. As income for digital nomads is earned from foreign sources, it is not subject to Namibian income tax.
tax_system.special_regimes: The source-based system is the key benefit.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Not applicable to the foreign income of digital nomads.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable for DNV holders. For local employees, the employee and employer each contribute a small, fixed amount to the Social Security Commission.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Digital Nomad Visa holders are not required to contribute to Namibian social security.

benefits.healthcare: It is a mandatory requirement for the visa to have a valid international health insurance policy. The public health system is not comprehensive, and private healthcare is recommended.
benefits.pension: No access to the local pension system.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity. The application is submitted online via the Namibia Investment Promotion and Development Board (NIPDB) portal. Once approved, you receive a confirmation letter, and the visa is issued upon arrival at the airport.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Difficult for non-residents on a temporary visa. Relying on international banking is standard.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The visa program is well-defined. General administration can be slow. English is an official language, which is an advantage.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official guidelines.

visas.visa_length: Up to 12 or 23 months depending on nationality.
visas.eligible_citizens: Citizens from eligible countries, aged 18-30 or 18-35.
visas.bonuses_incentives: Access to diverse outdoor activities.
visas.remarks: ü•ù For young travelers, not a true nomad visa. Primary purpose must be tourism, with work being incidental. Strict age (18-35) and nationality requirements apply. Remote work is tolerated, but the visa is not designed for it.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: New Zealand does not offer a specific digital nomad visa. The most common pathway for remote work is the Working Holiday Visa, which has strict age and nationality requirements.
legal_pathways.self_employment: The 'Entrepreneur Work Visa' is for those who want to buy or start a business in New Zealand, requiring a minimum capital investment of NZD $100,000 and a detailed business plan.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: The 'Active Investor Plus Visa' requires a minimum investment of NZD $15 million.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: If you are in New Zealand for more than 183 days in any 12-month period, you are considered a tax resident and must pay tax on your worldwide income. Progressive rates range from 10.5% to 39%.
tax_system.special_regimes: A four-year 'transitional resident' status is available for new migrants and returning New Zealanders, which exempts most foreign-sourced income (except employment income) from tax. This could potentially apply to some on a Working Holiday Visa, but professional advice is needed.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Non-residents are taxed only on their New Zealand-sourced income.

contribution_rates.employed: There are no direct social security deductions from pay. The system is funded from general taxation. The 'ACC' levy for accident insurance is collected alongside income tax.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Self-employed individuals also pay the ACC levy.

benefits.healthcare: The public healthcare system is subsidized for residents, citizens, and holders of work visas valid for two years or longer (which includes many Working Holiday Visa holders).
benefits.pension: The voluntary 'KiwiSaver' pension scheme is available for those on a work visa.
benefits.unemployment: Unemployment benefits are generally restricted to citizens and permanent residents.

bureaucracy.visa_process: Moderate complexity. Working Holiday Visa applications are done online and are usually processed quickly, but quotas for some countries fill up almost instantly when they open.
bureaucracy.bank_account: Relatively easy. Many banks allow you to start the process online before arrival and finalize it with your passport and visa in person.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The system is efficient, well-organized, and highly digital. Getting an IRD number (tax number) is a straightforward online process and essential for any work.
bureaucracy.source: https://www.newzealandnow.govt.nz/live-in-new-zealand/visas-and-immigration

visas.bonuses_incentives: No local income tax on foreign earnings.
visas.remarks: üá∏üá® Simple, low-cost application for a slice of paradise. No specific income requirement, but must show proof of funds/employment. Applicant must have valid medical and travel insurance. The application is for a 'Visitor's Permit' under the workcation program.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: The 'Workcation Program' provides a Visitor's Permit for up to one year for remote workers. It does not have a minimum income requirement, but applicants must prove they are an employee or business owner and have sufficient funds.
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the Workcation program.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: Residency can be obtained through significant investment in a business that benefits the local economy, but this is a much more complex path.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: Participants in the Workcation program are not considered tax residents and are not liable for tax on their foreign-sourced income. For residents, a progressive income tax applies, starting at 15%.
tax_system.special_regimes: The tax exemption is the key benefit.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: Not applicable to Workcation participants on their foreign income.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable for Workcation participants. For local employment, both employee and employer contribute to the Seychelles Pension Fund.
contribution_rates.self_employed: Workcation participants are not required to contribute.

benefits.healthcare: It is a mandatory requirement for the permit to have a valid international health insurance policy. Participants do not access the public health system.
benefits.pension: No access to the local pension system.

social_security.source: Claude, based on standard DNV program structures.

bureaucracy.bank_account: Difficult for non-residents on a temporary permit. Relying on international banking is standard.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The visa program is streamlined. General administration on the islands can be slow. French and English are official languages.

visas.bonuses_incentives: Tax exemption if staying less than 183 days.
visas.remarks: üáøüá¶ Newly launched! Applications opened in June 2024. Must earn over R1 million/year (approx. $55,000 USD). You become a tax resident if you stay over 183 days in a 12-month period. Applications must be submitted at a South African embassy or consulate.

legal_pathways.digital_nomad_visa: A new Digital Nomad Visa is available for remote workers earning at least R1 million per year. The visa can be issued for up to three years.
legal_pathways.self_employment: This is covered by the Digital Nomad Visa.
legal_pathways.investment_visa: A business visa is available for those who invest a significant amount (e.g., R5 million) into a new or existing business in South Africa.

tax_system.personal_income_tax: If you are in South Africa for more than 183 days in a 12-month period, you are considered a tax resident and are liable for tax on your worldwide income. Progressive rates range from 18% to 45%.
tax_system.special_regimes: No special tax regimes exist for digital nomads.
tax_system.non_resident_tax: For stays under 183 days, you are not a tax resident and are not taxed on your foreign-sourced income.

contribution_rates.employed: Not applicable for DNV holders. For local employees, a 1% contribution from both employee and employer is made to the Unemployment Insurance Fund (UIF).
contribution_rates.self_employed: Digital Nomad Visa holders are not required to contribute to South African social security.

benefits.healthcare: It is a mandatory requirement for the visa to have valid medical insurance. The public health system is under-resourced, and all expats rely on the high-quality but expensive private healthcare system.
benefits.pension: No access to the local pension system.

social_security.source: Claude, based on standard DNV program structures.

bureaucracy.visa_process: High complexity. Applications must be submitted in person at a South African embassy or VFS Global centre abroad. Requires extensive documentation, including medical and radiological reports. Processing times are known to be very long (often several months).
bureaucracy.bank_account: Difficult to open without a valid long-term residence permit.
bureaucracy.general_admin: The Department of Home Affairs is known for being extremely slow and bureaucratic. The new visa's processes are still being established and may face significant delays.
bureaucracy.source: Claude, based on synthesis of official guidelines and extensive expat reporting.
